results.description:
StoryForward NYC, in association with the Film Society of Lincoln Center, is pleased to present our first Hands-On Intensive Workshop, featuring Interlude’s V.P. of Creative, Alex Vlack who will be presenting Treehouse, an innovative web-based platform designed for creators to develop interactive video content.


Join us on Sunday, April 24th from 11AM to 2PM at the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center for a one-of-a-kind intimate session where you will learn how to write, produce and edit interactive content.

Please come prepared with a laptop; free WiFi will be provided. Space is extremely limited, so RSVP today.


About Interlude/Treehouse:

Interlude is pioneering a new form of media in which video can respond to a person’s actions and interests in real-time.

Stories told using our patented technology can adapt in a multitude of directions; like in a video game, the viewer steps into the story to make choices that affect dialogue, and even the plot, at any particular moment in time. This means that viewers are offered nearly infinite experiences in live-action video within a single piece of content.  The result is highly engaging game-like videos that consumers play over and over.  We partner with entertainment companies, independent creators, and top brands to create episodic series that are distributed widely through a network of affiliates on the mobile web, mobile apps, and the web.

Interlude investors include Sequoia Capital, NEA, Marker, and Innovation Endeavors.  Strategic investors include MGM, Intel Capital, Warner Music Group and Samsung.

The company is based in New York, with offices in Tel Aviv, and Los Angeles.

About Alex Vlack:

Alex Vlack, VP Creative at Interlude, has twenty years of experience producing books, documentary and narrative films, videos, commercials, television programs, exhibition installations and interactive projects.

Mr. Vlack wrote, produced, and directed (with Damani Baker) Still Bill, a feature documentary on the musician Bill Withers, which has won numerous awards for best documentary and aired on Showtime. He also wrote and produced High Falls, a short film with Maggie Gyllenhaal and Peter Sarsgaard, which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival and won Best Short Film at the Woodstock Film Festival. Additionally, he wrote and produced some 40 on-air and print campaigns for Puma, online and theatrical advertising for The Gap, and content for a variety of organizations.

In 2011, Mr. Vlack founded the media department at Ralph Appelbaum Associates, building a team of producers and content specialists, as well as talented artists in various disciplines, initially to begin work on the Museum of Jewish History and Tolerance Center in Moscow and IBM’s THINK exhibit for their centennial at Lincoln Center.  In its brief existence, the media department has completed nearly $40M worth of productions, from Chattanooga to Berlin, from multi-screen installations to haptic interactives to traditional linear documentary films to soundscapes.  His final project there was a 200-monitor installation for the 2015 World Expo, which was the focus of a Daniel Libeskind-designed pavilion.

As executive producer, he launched videos for Apple products, among them the iPad and the iPhone 4. He produced and editedWisdom and Music, each a book and a feature film on cultural figures, from Nelson Mandela to Jane Goodall to Ravi Shankar. He oversaw production of the exhibition Wisdom, at the World Financial Center and the National Library in Sydney.

Mr. Vlack wrote, produced, and directed the Centers for Disease Control’s two-hour Global Symphony, a nineteen-screen media installation of animations and documentary films. He wrote, produced, and directed the orientation film at the National Museum of the Marine Corps and wrote all media treatments for the Harley-Davidson Museum in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

For New York Times Television, Mr. Vlack produced the NOVA “Battle Plan Under Fire” and “Raising the Flag”, an hour-long documentary.  Previous to his time at NYT he worked on documentary series for Bill Moyers and literacy programs for PBS.

Mr. Vlack holds a B.A. in writing and religion from Columbia University.
results.name: SFNYC Workshop: Creating Interactive Videos with Interlude

Smorgasburg at Prospect Park starts at 11:00 am. At 1:00 pm we'll walk over to the South Entrance of BBG and see the Cherry Trees in full bloom.

 The popular Sunday Food Fair that used to be in Brooklyn Bridge Park has moved to Prospect Park Near the LeFrak Center. There are all sorts of trendy food makers to satisfy any craving or diet (vegan, gluten-free, paleo etc.) The LeFrak center has picnic tables and I will try and arrive early to reserve a few (if folks wanted to join me that would be great). 

The site is near 2/3, F/G, and Q/S subway stops. Here are links about the event and the location. (http://www.smorgasburg.com/2015/08/sunday-smorg-is-moving-to-prospect-park/, https://www.prospectpark.org/visit-the-park/places-to-go/lefrak-center-lakeside/) 

At about 1:00pm, we could head over to the South Entrance of Brooklyn Botanical Gardens (455 Flatbush Avenue) (http://www.bbg.org). The BBG’s famous cherry trees will be at their peak bloom. (The actual Cherry Tree Festival won’t happen until the weekend of April 30th—so we will miss the major crowds.) 

Admissions is $12, but you may be able to apply for a free membership with a valid IDNYC card http://www1.nyc.gov/site/idnyc/benefits/museums-and-cultural-institutions.page#brooklyn. (Note: you need to apply for membership in advance and you may need to have been issued a card in 2016.)

results.description:
Everyone is invited to our platform meetings.

The Sunday School meets at the same time. The Sunday School at the Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County helps children aged 2-14 explore and develop their moral and critical thinking skills through fun and interactive lessons and field trips. We meet weekly at 11am on Sundays for 1.5 hours while the adults of the Ethical Culture Society are attending the platform meeting. Our wide ranging curriculum allows kids to examine themselves, their community and the world in general. We teach about different cultures, philosophies and religions. We encourage our students to ask questions, think for themselves and make up their own minds about the bigger questions in life. Our children develop strong values and ethical standpoints. The Sunday School Graduation Rite of Passage, completed by our 8th graders, allows them to present to the community how their Sunday School experience has informed their moral and ethical development.

results.description:
Richard Kiniry will give a talk entitled:  Faith For Faithless Times

Ethical Humanism claims each person plays a part in creating our human world. So, are we proud of our handiwork? While Ethical Society members may have trouble living up to that belief, most human beings have never heard of the idea. Trying to live that principle could change our world and human beings can learn to find their meaning in life in positive involvement in their relations with others and the natural world. Ethical Humanism is a very good idea; we ought to spread the word.

Richard Kiniry is Leader Emeritus of the Ethical Humanist Society of Philadelphia, a humanist religious fellowship.  He spent his college years in a Catholic seminary, raised chickens in India with Peace Corps for two years, and had his own Stained Glass business for many years.  Mr. Kiniry is a graduate of, among other institutions, the Humanist Institute and the training program of the Ethical Culture Movement.  He is also the former  Director of Camp Linden, a children’s camp in Chester County, PA and a member of the Board of The East Fairmount Park Alliance, a neighborhood community group in North Philadelphia

A ceremony including the reading of the Proclamation, the laying of a wreath, a minute’s silence, the flag of the Irish Republic raising and the national anthems. 

Location  to be announced. 

APRIL 24, 2016  -  1:00 - 5:00 PM - PIER A, BATTERY PARK 


Celebration of the Irish and New York:
A very special afternoon of events featuring Irish-American music, dance, film, theatre, food, lectures and much more.   Pier A, Battery Park, NYC.

I will post more details and send out an update when more details, musical events, time schedules etc. are announced. It should be a fun, event packed afternoon. Everyone is welcome. Hope the weather is good!

IMPROV FOR ACTORS - On Your Own

In this Improv for Actors workshop you will learn techniques that help you to relax and feel more grounded when performing alone on stage. Each participant will have the opportunity to take the stage alone and deliver an improvised monologue.

A fun safe and non-competitive environment is created in which each participant will learn how to work through inhibitions and tap into their imaginations.

Suggested Donation: $15* (or whatever you can pay)

*free drink with $15 donation

*most improv classes in NYC cost $35-$50 per class

results.description:
http://nyncs.org/extravaganza/

Occultism: From the Farthest Reaches to the 19th century Parlor.
In the 19th century, the America was at the forefront of "new, industrial age" challenging old, constrictive notions business,society and etiquette.  New discoveries world wide of ancient civilizations and spirituality, the influx and assimilation of new cultures fanned the flames of what would become the Occult movement.  Drawing from African, Egyptian, Creole, Eastern and Western European & Asian sources:  Divination, Seances, Tarot, Crystal Ball, Palmistry, Phrenology,  Tea Leaves, Runes, Astrology, Intuitive readings of all forms took center stage in the upscale and burgeoning middle class Parlors of America.  Beginning as leisure time entertainment these ancient arts and beliefs laid the groundwork for the "new Occult age" : encouraging Americans to challenge old, constrictive notions of religion, science and society.      

This is a lecture and steam punk day in Brooklyn.....B will be presenting and spending the remainder of the day reading tarot on the grounds.

Nice group, beautiful piece of bklyn history.....

this one's at no cost....hope you can come and enjoy the day.....and the lecture!
results.name: Occultism: From the Farthest Reaches to the 19th century Parlor.

results.description:
Time for another day at our favorite games hangout!  We'll be highlighting a number of pony themed versions of games: Secret Hitler as Secret Changeling, Gravwell, our homemade Ticket to Ride map for Equestria, and good old favorites MLP Monopoly and Pony Races.  As well as everything else we have here and more.

I can offer sleepover space after the Saturday episode screening, let me know in the comments if you want a spot.


My apartment is in downtown Jersey City NJ.  Take any subway to the World Trade Center area, then the PATH subway from WTC one stop to Exchange Place station, and it's a short walk from there.  (The Path takes pay-per-ride Metrocards but not unlimited.)  No cost other than transportation, although we might chip in for food together

It's an all day event, come and go anytime, we keep playing until midnight or so.   Feel free to bring video games to plug in too.


My cell phone if you need to contact or have any trouble finding the place: five five one - 9 9 8 - zero 6 one 6. Come have fun!

DRIVING/PARKING: Parking should be available in the area, you just might have to look around for a block or two, and some streets are residents only.
results.name: Games at VikingErik's place, Pony Re-Theme Edition

results.description:
This is a co-ed adult pick-up game 6v6 or 7 v7 depending on attendance. 90 minutes with two 45 minute halves. No slide tackling or rough play. We play with Pugg goals. Pinnies provided.  Shin guards are recommended.


This pick up game is hosted by Coach Moe, Please bring  $4 in cash.


PLEASE UPDATE YOUR RSVP BY MIDNIGHT BEFORE THE GAME!

• RSVPs close by 9:45AM (2 hours before the start time)


• No shows and those who didn't update their RSVP at least 2 hours before the game will be red carded after the second offense, which means that we have the right to edit your RSVP.


Directions by subway or bus:

2 and 3 trains to Clark St.

A and C trains to High St.


F train to York St.


N and R trains to Court St.


Weather policy:

In case of inclement weather we will send out an email to notify you at least two hours before meeting time.

What to bring:

Please note that Cadman Plaza park is a turf field. Turf shoes are preferred. Please bring water or sports drink. Please bring a ball if you have one.


By RSVP-ing YES you agree to the following:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Brooklyn Soccer Club activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Brooklyn Soccer Club Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Brooklyn Soccer Club or activities.
results.how_to_find_us: Coach Moe will be wearing a neon yellow pinnie.
results.name: PICK UP GAME 90 mins SUN 11:45 AM Cadman Plaza

group.name: Brooklyn Soccer Club - Adult Soccer lessons and pickup games

results.description:
Please be there on time so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER :)

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. You will not be allowed to play with cleats.

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and ground kick-ins and pop-up goals.

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on 173 West 108th street , The entrance gate is located on west 108th street and Manhattan ave.

Check the MTA's website for any service changes: www.mta.info

Time: Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed! 

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a full refund. This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List: If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, you will be sent an automated e-mail letting you know that a spot has just openned :). If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text me or call me at[masked]-5725.

See you on the field.

Paul.
results.name: Soccer Sunday -@west 108th Street Field - 11:45am

results.description:
Direct from a sold out run in London, join us in seeing this new hit Broadway musical! You will also meet other Meetup members at our Pre-Mingle and then sit together at the show. 

We will meet for the pre-mingle (NOON) at a local bar/pub near the theater, where we will hand out the show tickets.  The pre-mingle location will be sent to the email address used to purchase ticket, week of show date.  

We'll leave the pre-mingle at 1:30 so we have enough time to settle into our seats for the 2pm show. The group will be sitting together in the rear Mezz.

Food and drink will be available for purchase at pre-mingle. This event is not meant to be a gender balanced or age/ethnic specific. All are welcome.

Package for the tickets & pre-mingle - $87.50 to $97.50 (depending upon how early you purchase your ticket) 

*Get your tickets ASAP Prepay Only

Event. Get Tickets Here

*Prepay Only Event. RSVP doesn't hold your spot. Must buy ticket to attend. 

This hit musical based on the best-selling novel by BRET EASTON ELLIS is set in the excess of 1980s Manhattan, where young and handsome Wall Street banker Patrick Bateman pursues his darkest American dreams. BENJAMIN WALKER (Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson) leads a first-class cast, including Tony Award® winner ALICE RIPLEY (Next to Normal), HELÉNE YORKE (Bullets Over Broadway), Tony nominee JENNIFER DAMIANO (Next to Normal), and DREW MOERLEIN in his Broadway debut.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cZ4DgTUJ2sM

Featuring a score by DUNCAN SHEIK, the Tony and Grammy Award®-winning composer of Spring Awakening, and reinvented for the stage by Olivier Award-winning director RUPERT GOOLD (King Charles III), writer ROBERTO AGUIRRE-SACASA (“Glee”), Tony-nominated choreographer LYNNE PAGE (La Cage Aux Folles) and three-time Olivier Award-winning scenic designer ES DEVLIN (tours for Adele, Beyonce, U2, Kanye West), this new musical is the hottest ticket in New York.

Prepay Only Event. Get Tickets Here

results.description:
Hi ladies, 

I'm a certified yoga instructor and I thought it might be fun to do a free yoga class just for my meetup. Please join me on Sunday, March 20th at 12pm at The Yoga Collective for a 1 hour Dynamic Vinyasa Class. This class is open to all levels but it will be beginner friendly so if you've never tried yoga before and always wanted to, this will be the perfect opportunity to do so.

The Yoga Collective is fully equipped so if you don't have a mat, blocks or straps, don't worry, it will be provided. The only thing that you need to bring is water and your desire to have fun while doing yoga. Space is limited so please rsvp early and only if you can definitely make it. 

See you there :)

Sam

results.description:
Join us for this three and half hour instructed figure drawing session. 

This session is for beginners and advanced beginners who are interested in figure drawing but feel they need to understand the basics to make real progress. 

• We will work from a live model for the entire session.

• All materials are provided for students.


Our goal is to give students clear instruction as well as focused goals they can achieve during the session. Additionally, we provide information they can use long after the class ends, in their own drawing. 

We will cover: 

1) Gesture Drawing - what is it, why do we do it, how does it benefit us. 

2) Understanding Basic Form - how simple drawing knowledge helps us to understand drawing the figure. (This is the largest section of the class with the most beneficial drawing techniques we can use well into the future.) 

3) Strategies for Long Poses - beginning to shade form and simplify shapes when it comes to the figure. 

The space we will work in (but of course from a figure.)

Instructor Simon Levenson is the founder of Drawing New York and teaches drawing at The National Art Club, The Morgan Library and Museum and The Museum of The City of New York. His oil paintings are represented by Cavalier Galleries Inc. 


If you have any questions please feel free to email simon(at)drawingnewyork.com

Thank you, 

Simon Levenson
results.how_to_find_us: The doorman will direct you.
results.name: Introduction to Figure Drawing

results.description:
Please read carefully: This event is being hosted by Dave Cervini's  newyorksocialnetwork.com and several of their partner Meet Up groups.  The number of people you see registered on your Meet Up represent only a portion of those actually attending. If you have any questions or want to know how many are attending from all groups please contact the event host at [masked]

Sammy Social is a member of several social groups in the city.  One particular day Sammy attended several events, met with friends and toured some historic sites near Herald Square.  By the end of the night Sammy met a horrible fate and the police need your help to solve this case!   Join us for this fun night where you will join with other members of our group to set out on a mission to find clues to solve Sammy's case. Along the way you will learn amazing bits and pieces of NYC history that you probably never knew.  The best part is that at the end of the hunt you can socialize with all the teams to talk about your adventure!

*** PLEASE BRING EXACT CHANGE $10 AT THE EVENT ***

How it works:

-Arrive at The Playwright for socializing, cocktails and registration.

-If you don't have a team we will put you with other fun people in teams of 4-5.

-Once you are on a team you will receive a sheet retracing Sammy's steps that day.  You will go out into the neighborhood to find clues and fact that will help you solve Sammy's Case.  Along the way you will also learn a little NYC history!

-Each group will have 90 minutes to find as many clues and solve the case.  You will return to The Playwright for more socializing, cocktails and food if you wish, while we tally up the scores.

Can I come alone?  Yes, 98% of those attending will likely come on their own.

Dress code?  Be comfortable but keep it neat.

What will we be looking for?  You will be directed to several historic sights and places from Penn Station to 5th avenue, 32nd street to 35th street.  You will need to give us details on what you see and find.  It is actually pretty easy and fun!

What is included?  $10 includes admission to the hunt and drink specials at the bar.
results.name: The Great Midtown Murder Mystery Scavenger Hunt (DayTime)

results.description:
Hello! Join Mike G as you will be his guest for a Great Day! 

Free! 

 The Greenbrook Nature Sanctuary opens its gates to the public April 24th noon to 3pm as an introduction to the sanctuary and membership growth effort. View the award winning Orientation Center, join short guided nature walk(s) (no free roaming) enjoy light refreshments. 


The Greenbrook Nature Sanctuary is having a "Visitors Day or "Open House " 
http://www.njpalisades.org/greenbrook.html 


When: Sun, April 24, 12pm – 3pm @Palisades Nature Association 12–3 PM at Greenbrook Sanctuary in Tenafly. 


For more information: Please Message Mike G Your Host

Greenbrook Sanctuary is a 165-acre woodland preserve on top of the Palisades in Tenafly and Alpine, New Jersey. The Sanctuary is managed and maintained for the use of its members by the Palisades Nature Association, a non-profit organization founded in 1947. 

The entrance is off U.S. Route 9W, 4.7 miles north of the George Washington Bridge

Directions Here


See you soon,

Mike G

This is an opportunity for you to get your jam on!

This meetup focuses on giving members opportunities to solo, play off each other, experiment with different percussion sounds, and rhythm games.

I bring a few drums and percussion instruments, but I advise you to bring your own if have. 'Veteran' members, please bring a small instrument for someone to play.

I also suggest you bring:

-Water and/or food to share
-Small folding stool or blanket to sit on
-A song and/or rhythm to share

Every meetup is also an opportunity for YOU to faciliate!!! Please let me know before we start if you are interested in facilitating.

Let's play well TOGETHER!!!

results.description:
Loving ourself is more than thinking we are smart, pretty and worthy. Most women struggle with real authentic self-confidence. Though many women feel good about aspects of themselves professionally or personally, there is often a gaping hole inside that makes them feel separate and strange. This is normal. 

Today's workshop will address authentic confidence vs. our common understanding of feeling good about ourselves. 

You will leave with:

- Knowing Authentic verses Traditional Confidence 
- Increased Self-Confidence
- Empowered, Strong and Clear
- Feeling More of Yourself
- Supported by A Community of Like-Minded Women

** $12 cash payment keeps making low-cost, high-quality programming available to a diverse community of women. Thank you kindly. 

** Sliding scale available for women with current financial challenges. Please contact [masked] prior to the meeting. 

** Participants will purchase a cup of tea for our tea time, separately from the cafe directly. :) 

**Everyone is encouraged to leave a bit of extra time afterwards to connect with women in the group on a personal level to keep actively building community.
results.how_to_find_us: It's a tiny cafe - you'll see us. My cell is 917-717-8275 if you need help. :)
results.name: Manhattan: Authentic Self-Love

results.description:
Click the link below to purchase a ticket to this event:


http://www.bigmaven.com/experience/behind-the-scenes-the-abandoned-ellis-island-hospital-complex/

Tickets: $69 (includes round-trip ferry tickets)

Join New York Adventure Club for an all-access hard hat tour of the abandoned hospital on Ellis Island.

Our adventure will take us through select areas of the abandoned 750-bed Ellis Island Hospital Complex, including exclusive, NYAC-only access to the second floor of both the Contagious Disease Wards (used for the treatment of PTSD during WWII) and Administration Building.

While our tour begins at 2:00pm in front of the Ellis Island Visitor Center information desk, we will meet at 12:00pm in front of Castle Clinton in Battery Park in order to board the Ellis Island ferry ahead of time. Full meeting location details will be provided in a confirmation email upon ticket purchase.

Your ticket will include the Ellis Island tour and round-trip ferry ticket, which the Adventure Club facilitator will hand out in front of Castle Clinton.

Click here to see pictures from our last visit to the Ellis Island Hospital Complex!
results.name: NY Adventure Club: Behind-The-Scenes @ Abandoned Ellis Island Hospital Complex

results.description:
Are you interested in trying yoga but not sure what you’re doing? Whether you have never stepped foot in a yoga studio before or you’ve tried a couple classes, this is the workshop for you! We will focus on the fundamentals of a Vinyasa yoga class in a safe and nurturing environment, leaving you with the confidence and enthusiasm to continue along your yoga journey! The class size is limited giving you more personalized attention.

What you will learn:
-What yoga is
-Basic yoga terms
-15-20 common yoga poses and how to get into them safely and correctly
-Typical, simple breathing exercises
-How to use props confidently (even if the teacher doesn’t use them)
-Modifications for any injuries you may have
-As well as answer any questions about your yoga practice


Sunday, April 24th
Noon-3pm
$40 pre-register, $50 at the door


What to wear? Comfortable clothing you can move in. You might break a sweat so consider that too.

What to bring? An open mind, a gentle attitude and a water bottle. You may also want
to bring a hand towel in case you work up a sweat. If you own a yoga mat feel free to bring it, however the studio has house mats to borrow.
results.name: Learn your yoga basics!! Beginners Workshop!

results.name: FRENCHIE MEETUP!!

results.description:
Anyone up for a group workout? Come and meet some people you'll be racing with! This is 6 days before the Spartan NJ Beast, your last chance to see if your endurance training has been working because after this you should taper your training before race day. Bring all the water and supplies you'll carry for the Beast, and wear whatever gear you want to test out. Nothing new on race day. Due to the diverse abilities of members, the entire group may not stay together. Everyone should pick a buddy of similar ability to hike/run with.

The trail head is at the Bear Mountain Inn area, where there is a $10 parking fee. About a mile from the Inn, there is free parking at the GPS coordinates above. So we will meet at the free parking area and walk/jog the mile to the Inn as a warmup.

Here's a map of the route: http://ow.ly/4mXAYz We'll be hiking up the Major Welch trail, and then running down the AT, for as many loops as anyone wants to do. The route comes back down to the parking lot every time, so if some people only want to do 1 lap, awesome. If people want to do laps until their legs fall off, that works as well. The loop is about 3.5 miles and has about 1200 feet of elevation gain (and loss. It is a loop after all). See you there!
AROO!
results.name: Prelude to the Beast!

results.description:
Photographer & Model Photoshoot Society presents:

"Member's Choice: Glamour Galore w/Stephanie Dec & Stacy Winters - April 24th"

We are back this month with two of the best models we've had the pleasure to shoot with, Stephanie Dec and Stacy Winters. Both are amazing with posing and giving you the perfect shot! Plus they are both such a blast and super fun. This month we are celebrating member, Michael Cotallessa's birthday with this shoot and his top two favorite models. So, let's all wish Michael a happy birthday. (technically it's on the 18th.)

About Member's Choice Shoots:

This type of shoot is a way of giving back to the members on special occasions, such as a birthdays. With this shoot, a member will pick out their dream team group of models and we'll put together a shoot around some of the member's concepts.

About the Shoot:

We have three looks planned with a fourth look pending time. Weather permitting, we'll get to do some outdoor shooting. Michael's ideas are swimwear, sexy sporty (it is baseball season after all) and lingerie. Plus, we have a few other ideas from Michael's series pending time. For outdoor shooting, feel free to bring your speed lights, reflectors and any modifiers to get shots in your preferred portable lighting setups. Indoors, we'll have our strobe and LED setups.

RSVP:

We have setup a deposit system to hold a spot for a shoot. So, please only sign up when you are sure of your attendance and ready to make the deposit to hold your spot. (This also lets anyone on a waitlist able to join the shoot if you are not sure of your attendance yet.) Your spot is not held till the deposit is received and I'll send you a confirmation message or confirm your spot on the Meetup page. All deposits need to be received immediately upon signup or within 5 days of the shoot or we will have to fill the unconfirmed spot/s ASAP if there is a waitlist or cancel the shoot (existing deposits returned) if the minimum RSVP is not met. (No, deposit is needed if you are on the waitlist but check back to see if your waitlist status has been updated to "Yes".)

Total Cost: $80

Deposit: $20 (PayPal)

(Don't mark the checkbox on the PayPal page as that adds the surcharge automatically. If we have to return a deposit for any reason, it will be less than originally deposited.)

Balance due at time of shoot: $60, Cash preferred, Credit Cards/Paypal ok with $5 added for surcharge.

Non-Commercial Release PDF will be emailed to you at the email address given on the sign in sheet.

Model: 

Stephanie Dec: MM#[masked]

(Photos provided by model for promotional purposes. All rights their respective owners.)

Stacy Winters: Facebook 

(Photos provided by model and model's social media page for promotional purposes only. Photo Credits: NikitaBoyd)

Policy and Disclaimers:

One-on-One: The model will be available for one half hour one on one shoot after the first two hours in the Meetup. If you want to pre-book time before the shoot, send me a message.

Shared One-on-Ones: We are also implementing a system that has been working for the past few Meetups. It's the sharing of a half hour one on one with a fellow photographer. It can be shared together for the whole half hour or 15 minutes each photographer. 

____________________________________________________________________

About the Studio:

The studios is a beautiful 3,000 sq. ft., climate controlled,  fully functional studio. (Professional in-house lights, props, various seamless backdrops, actual commercial photography sets, kitchen, waiting room, meeting/presentation room, the works!) It's conveniently located to major highways and a 20-30 minute public transportation ride to and from NY.

About The Meetup Format:

We will keep the group small although we have the space to accommodate a big group. This keeps things from feeling rushed and overwhelming. Each photographer will have a set amount of time per look. This will allow you to  shoot as you would in an actual client shoot and not have to worry about the number of shots you are taking. (This proved to be ideal in our previous shoots as far as being able to get "the shot" and enough time to do so. Think of it as a mini one-on-one time with the model.) During the shoot we may opt to give a theme a direction to shoot for. As it would be for an actual client. (Ex: If the setup calls for a "cover shot" then it will give you a direction to aim for and to consider what equipment to use or what mood to capture.) No worries, bring what lens or lenses you have, you'll learn to use what you have for best results. We strive to bring forth real world conditions and parameters so there is a methodology to a setup or theme.

Check-in Procedure and Disclaimers:

Check-in - When you arrive, there will be a quick check-in. This will mostly be so you can read and adhere to the studio/group shoot guidelines and make payment for the shoot before we start. This will also let us send you the release forms in PDF format if we don't have physical copies available.

Releases - We will have one non-commercial release signed by the model through the studio only. (No additional releases will be signed.) If you need a commercial release signed, you can make arrangements with the model directly. Additional compensation for this is between the model and photographer.

Right to Refuse - We have the right to refuse a member's RSVP to the Meetup. It's a small community and models keep detailed info on photographers also. If we feel there is justifiable reason to refuse a RSVP, we will exercise that right.

Signups - Please signup when you know you will attend. If the signup passes the point to book another model and then we get no shows it's not fair to your fellow photographers who would be on a waiting list. It also puts the organizers in a tough spot, financially after booking an additional model to compensate for a bigger group. In case of no show, we will have to remove you from the group. When emergencies come up, followup with an email and we can make exceptions on a case by case basis. 

Deposit - We have implemented a deposit system to insure that the minimum RSVP is met to hold the shoot. (Which varies from shoot to shoot.) This will ensure that the financials are or will be in place for the model/s beforehand. This deposit will be non-refundable, so make sure you sign up and pay the deposit when you are sure you will be able to attend. Signing up to the Meetup page does not ensure your spot until the deposit is made at the Paypal link provided on each event page. As the shoot date comes closer, if you have not paid the deposit, we will fill the unconfirmed spot immediately. You will receive a confirmation message or a confirmation comment on the Meetup page you are signing up for. Two days before the shoot, if the minimum RSVP has not been met then we will opt to cancel the shoot and refund any deposits already sent. This will give the model some time to book another gig if possible. But as usual, always check the Meetup page up to the date of the shoot for any updates.

Model Cancellation - If a model cancels/no show or a last minute model change occurs, you will have the option to cancel beforehand or not attend the Meetup on the day of, if it happens upon arrival to the Meetup. (Any refunds will be given or credit toward a future Meetup as per your request.)

Waitlist - When you are on a waitlist, please be mindful as this is also considered a RSVP of availability. So, if we add another model or someone cancels, your wait list status may upgrade to a "Yes" automatically. Please be on the lookout for updates on the Meetup page as Meetup sometimes takes longer to notify of a status change.

Updates - Updates will be made on this page up to the date of the Meetup or the night before. Emails will also be sent but Meetup emails are not always reliable to be sent to a receiver right away. (I've heard of emails arriving 3 hours later if at all.)

Postponements - Weather considerations will be made the night before a shoot or on the day of and the Meetup page will be updated as well as emails sent if a postponement occurs due to inclement weather or some other emergency. Lack of minimum RSVP to hold the event will also cause postponement of the shoot. The night before we would make the call wether to postpone so be on the look out for our email and Meetup page updates.

Any questions please email me at [masked]

results.description:
Updated March 5, 2016

WINTER (Dec-Feb)

As the city gets cold we play two times a week. We use Riverside Park with Morningside Park as a backup.

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd & West End) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Riverside Park (103rd & West End)

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

Damien 

[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the C local (B on weekdays) to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball/softball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.
results.why: It's fun and you like it...

results.description:
Are you looking for a complementary training to ENHANCE your overall well being on and off the track, to be more FLEXIBLE and RELEASE physical, mental and emotional tensions?


Are you looking for RELIEF from joint wear, tightness, pain, and/or discomfort?

$5 FOR FIRST CLASS TO CROSS TRAIN...

_________________________________________________

About Yin Yang Yoga...A typical Yoga class is ‘Yang’ in style and focuses on active heating and muscular contraction - by starting with ‘Yin’, a more passive, nourishing, and cooling practice, this uniquely designed class WILL enhance your alignment, performance, and overall sense of balance!


Why For Runners/Athletes? - Lengthening and releasing effect from repetitive movements on sheets of connective tissue can overtime shorten and tighten it in ingrained patterns around the muscles. This fascia restriction can make one more prone to having injuries, abnormal posture, and inefficiency, as well as asymmetrical weakening. By targeting rotated key areas in weekly Yin Yang Yoga For Runners class, one can experience tension release, fluid movement, and benefit from improved posture, circulation, injury prevention, as well as increased respiratory control and mental focus...

Each Yin Yang Yoga for Runners class begins with a series of held Yin/floor postures. While surrendering into the edge of each pose (for 2-5 minutes), students are guided to experience the discomforting stagnant energy and its release around the hips, thighs, and lower back, and be connected to the present moment. The Yang flow sequence designed to follow will allow students to integrate the newly released energy, joint spaces for greater circulation and achieve new level of flexibility and energy.  Guided Relaxation provided at the end will promise to be YUMMY!

__________________________________________________

Testimonies x3: "Jennifer is an awesome instructor. Her sessions are informative and her teaching style is patient, clear and inspires me to attain increased fitness. I look forward to attending her class. The very next day I was able to push through my usual 3-4 miles to complete a 6 mile run." Sandra

"I ran my best time running a 18 mile course the day after..." Lori

“ I started taking Jennifer's Yin/Yang Yoga for Runner's Class over the summer, and it was fantastic. I had never practiced yoga regularly before, and was pleasantly surprised at how it helped to improve my flexibility, running, and overall fitness. Jennifer is a great, hands-on teacher, and really knows how the body works. I highly recommend this class! ” Theresa

________________________________________________________

THIS PERFORMANCE ENHANCING WEEKLY 1.25 HOUR CLASS IS NOT OFFERED ANYWHERE ELSE IN NYC! COME CHECK IT OUT!

By Cash or Check

Did I Already Mention----FIRST CLASS FOR ONLY $ 5!! 

This Meet Up RSVP $15

Class Card $130/10-Class Card, or $13/class *****BEST DEAL!

Bring a Friend Get a Free Future Class Pass!

Please dress in layers (cool to start) and it's okay to eat prior.  Please message any questions and pass this invite to your friends. Thank you and see ya you on the mat!


Namaste, Jennifer, RYT-500hr

results.description:
Let's tour Brooklyn's crown jewel, Prospect Park, which its architects admired more than their other, earlier masterpiece, Central Park. It's certainly less crowded and it has more of a rustic, woodsy feel in many parts. Two new attractions: Smorgasburg, the craft-food fair, is now here on Sundays for the first time. Also here now are paddle boats on the scenic lake, which we can rent for $5 per half hour. (The boats cost $10 per hour for two people, $7.50 for four. We'll switch passengers after half an hour, which seems like plenty of time. During the half hour that you're not paddling, we'll either relax at the lake or maybe take a short walk. And you can skip the boats entirely if you wish, and instead join me on the short walks or hang out by the lake.) We'll also tour the historic Lefferts farmhouse (1783). 

PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING DETAILS SO YOU'RE PROPERLY PREPARED. 

DISTANCE: About 5 miles. We'll finish at around 5 PM, but you can leave earlier, of course.

PACE: Moderate (about 3 blocks in 4 minutes), NOT SLOW. If you wish to stroll rather than walk moderately, this is not the right walk for you.

LUNCH: Buy it at Smorgasburg craft-food fair, or bring your own. We'll eat at around 2 or 2:30 PM.

COST: $4-$5 if you rent a paddle boat; pay what you wish at the Lefferts House (suggested fee $3); $2 for me, in part to cover Meetup's organizer fee; and whatever you pay for lunch. 

TRANSPORTATION: 2 or 3 train to Grand Army Plaza station. Consult tripplanner.mta.org, maps.google.com/landing/transit/index.html, or both, since each is occasionally inaccurate.

WAITING LIST: Be patient. There will be many cancellations, especially at the last minute.
results.how_to_find_us: At the Grand Army Plaza station, take the exit that says "Plaza Street West/Grand Army Plaza. I'll be wearing a red hat.
results.name: Prospect Park, Smorgasburg & paddle boats!

results.description:
We got a lot of RSVPs for the first hike so I'm hosting another for those who can't make it. If you're RSVPd for the first hike then please DO NOT RSVP for this one. 


Hike at Watchung Reservation!

Meet in the parking lot outside the Trailside Nature and Science Center. We're going to hike the Historic Trail at Watchung Reservation. The trail is 6.5 miles long and passes along the Cooper Mine Gorge, the Deserted Village of Feltville, Lake Surprise and more. The trail is denoted by a pink square painted onto trees along the path.

The terrain is a mixed bag, with some flat sections and some rocky sections. We're going to travel over some gorges and dried river beds, not to mention there are some depressions in the ground along the path. Be careful. Bring shoes that you don't mind getting dirty. 

The hike will take about 3 hours, even more if we get sidetracked. It's a long hike. If anyone wants to cut it short we can take another path back to the parking lot.

Remember, we are meeting at the Trailside Nature and Science Center. There are several parking lots at the Watchung Reservation. Make sure you reach the right one.

I recommend that everyone carpool so that we don't take up the entire parking lot (this place is popular with hikers).

I'm looking forward to seeing everyone there!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in the parking lot.
results.name: Moderate Hike at Watchung Reservation # 2

results.description:
Note: Only RSVP if you are planning to show up.

First Timers, READ details before you RSVP. 

Where: The Cliffs at LIC, [masked]th Drive, Long Island City, NY

When: We usually climb between 1:00pm and 4:00 pm. There is no strict start time and the organizer(s) tries their best to be there around 1:00pm. We will pair off around 1.15ish and start climbing. 

Transportation: Subway: E, M trains to 23rd St-Ely Ave (1/2 block from gym) 7, G train to Court Square (2 blocks from gym)* N, Q train to Queens Borough Plaza (10min walk) *Walk to the E & M track for those bad weather days 

Metro North & LIRR: From Grand Central take 7 train 3 stops From Penn Station take Uptown E train to Court Square

Cost/Discount: $24 Day­pass during the meetup. For monthly/yearly membership, the Initiation Fee (currently $99) is waived (no discount on monthly dues, for yearly membership please inquire with the Cliffs for discount). Just mention "Rock & Ice" at the front desk in order to receive your discount. Gear rental is FREE for first-timers ONLY (first time visit to the facility). Regular gear  pricing info can be found here: http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/climbing/pricing/ 
For Beginners, Climbing 101/Top-rope basic class is offered 50% Off. Must sign­up and pay in advance by calling the Cliffs at 718­729­76125.</a>

How to meet us:  After you checked-in, to the right of the front desk there's a sitting area.If you see a group of people in there that's probably us come and say hi. If you are running late or can't find the group leave a message in the Comments section.  Food/drinks apres-climb at John Brown Smokehouse next door (or whichever resto the group decides). Even if you only want to have a beer with us, that is also acceptable :)

Notice to Beginners: If you have never climbed before, we encourage you to take the Climbing 101 class there before attending the meetup. We get a discounted price of $25 for the class (that's 50% Off original price if you do it the same day as the meet up and has to be scheduled in advance with them). This will also cover your day pass + gear for the day. Unfortunately we can't teach you how to belay or let you try to belay at the gym if you are not belay certified yet. We leave the teaching to the experts.  Check out Cliff's website for more details.  What to wear - comfortable clothes (think yoga).

Notice to newcomers: You need to pass a belay certification. If you had belayed before, the test takes couple of minutes. If you need a refresher, a test partner or belay partner, please see feel free to see me. Here is the link to The Cliffs LIC <a href="http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/">http://thecliffsclimbing.com/lic/

If you decide to stick with the sport, please peruse our message boards for good deals on climbing shoes and other gear.  Also if you find this group invaluable, please donate and pay your voluntary membership due ;) the Organizers will love you more ;)
results.name: Weekend Climbing at the Cliffs LIC

results.description:

http://www.philosopher.org/

http://www.socratescafemn.org/scindex2.html

http://www.philosopher.org/en/Socrates_Cafe.html

I look forward to meeting everyone, experiencing your "question" and our process and the ensuing conversation/discussion.

results.description:
Finally our signature event is here! 

Creativity Manor is for you if you could use a bit of an escape from the daily grind, working by yourself, and have tried to make your cat a sound advisor. How about mixing and mingling with real people? Whether you're naturally shy, introverted, outgoing, a quiet worker, or a bustling little busy bee, this is the event for you. Call it coworking, call it a much needed staycation, whatever you call it, you won't find anything else like it in the whole city. Did we mention the delicious food yet??

Tables, chairs, bean bags, couches, quiet areas, outdoor gardens, lofts, dark theaters, bright spacious nooks, natural light.... what more could you ask for as your favorite circumstances to get great work done? Have you thought about changing up your environment lately? Our community gathers every weekend. Check out our coworking calendar and experience for yourself the vibrant and supportive local community of friendly women that is alive and well! 

If you are a girl boss, feel free to just bring yourself and your devices of choice so you can get work done with the help of other skilled ladies.

If you are looking to just meet new friends, bring your hobby and you'll fit right in. We will have yoga, cooking, daytime camp fire, you can make your jewelry or knitting or whatever you like!

Anyone who is interested in staying the night is more than welcome. We will make smores and have a delicious dinner and breakfast buffet.
results.name: Staycation Winter Weekend Friends Mixer @ Creativity Manor

Hey Guys!

So this is our first official scheduled meetup! Chelsea Park, Sunday April 24th 2016 @ 1pm! This is one of our home courts and I'm excited to return back to this! It's been a long winter and I am itching to return to the courts and I hope you guys are too! So sign up! Cant wait to see you guys!

Location: Chelsea Courts on 28th St & 9th Ave in Manhattan.

Directions: There are several trains that are near the courts. The C or E train to 23rd St, or 1 train to 28th St, or N or R train to 28th St. If you decide to take any of these trains, once off, just walk towards 9th Ave and the park is between 9th and 10th ave on 28th St. Here is a map!


Weather Advisory: Weather Channel predicts mix of sun and clouds in the mid 60s. 


Cancellation Notice: Handball Meetups are only cancelled if there is a change of weather or last minute emergencies. I usually send weather updates via email the morning of the meetup so please keep an eye out for any updates that changes our meetups. 


Hope to see you guys there!

Sheena and Julian on 4/24 (Monica and Vijay on 4/23)

There are some great iconic buildings here, as well as Bethesda Terrace, which has a fountain (featured below) and beautiful architecture. results.description:
On Sunday, April 24 at 1 pm Green City Challenge will co-host a screening of Love Thy Nature at Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street in Manhattan.  Narrated by Liam Neeson, Love Thy Nature is a cinematic journey through the beauty and intimacy of our relationship with the natural world.  With mesmerizing artistry and fascinating details, the film explores how nature nourishes us.  Love Thy Nature shows us that a new era of connectedness with the natural world is key to ensuring our species’ future.  Avi Offer of Rotten Tomatoes said this of the film: “Breathtaking…Enthralling!  It will replenish your hope in mankind and nature.  A must see for everyone, young and old!”

Tickets are $12 for adults and $8 for children.  Green City Challenge is co-hosting the screening of Love Thy Nature to help raise funds for our organization.  Please buy your tickets today!  Here is the link:

http://27.formovietickets.com:2235/T.ASP?WCI=BT&Page=PickTickets&SHOWID=21197

For more information, go to www.lovethynature.com
results.name: Movie Screening : Love Thy Nature

results.description:
Auntie Guan's Kitchen

As usual, I will order a variety of dishes, some spicy, many with meat, and we will have Family style Lunch. No special diets. No vegetarians, gluten free etc.

We will share cost of meal+T&T+$2MU fee. Limit 8 people, Only members, no guests. After meal we will walk, probably to High Line and further.

Please be aware if you are a no show or if you cancel with 24 hours you will be removed from the group.

Sarina

</a> <a href="http://newyorkfood.typepad.com/.a/6a00d8341c58bb53ef01b8d1a4d7b1970c-popup">http://newyorkfood.typepad.com/.a/6a00d8341c58bb53ef01b8d1a4d7b1970c-250wi

Liaoning, said the waitress who speaks English best, translating for the owner. That Chinese province — you'd pass through it on the halting daylong train ride from Beijing to Pyongyang, the capital of North Korea — was the first home of this restaurant's chef. In emphasis, the owner brought a magazine clipping to my table about her original restaurant, in Flushing: Golden Palace.

This restaurant is, in fact, the second Auntie Guan's in Manhattan (the namesake auntie still owns Golden Palace, too). It's very new: The fishtank for fresh seafood is still dry, and a refrigerator case, probably intended for plates of cold appetizers, is bare. The grand-opening menu is less extensive than at Golden Palace, and it introduces many dishes from more-assimilated Chinese cuisines. (Greetings, General Tso.) Prices, of course, befit a Manhattan thoroughfare and not a side street off Kissena Blvd. — but factor in the cost of travel time, and a group dinner seems promising. (Hello again, crispy lamb.)

For example, noodles with minced pork and cucumber, also known as da lu mian or gravy noodles ($7.99); taro and sweet potato "wrapped" with syrup (on the house).

Auntie Guan's Kitchen
108 West 14th St. (Sixth-Seventh Aves.), Manhattan
[masked]
Also at 219 East 23rd St. (Second-Third Aves.)
[masked]
www.AuntieGuanKitchen.com

results.description:
All are welcome to attend the talk on the environmental importance of rain barrels. If you want a $25 ($95 for out-of-towners) rain-barrel to take home, please sign up. 

These barrels will help reduce our water bills by using rain water for our gardens instead of municipal water. Mountain Lakes sewer prices have recently gone up and are expected to go up again soon. Sewer pricing is based on water usage. Watering our gardens with rainwater is a win/win for both us and the environment.

We will assemble the rainbarrels in the workshop so bring an SUV or car that can carry it home. These barrels have been used to ship food, not chemicals. Mountain Lakes residents are welcome to one or more barrels. Please sign up for as many as you need. The barrels are subsidized by the Mountain Lakes Green Team, The Mountain Lakes Environmental Commission, and the Mountain Lakes Shade Tree Commission, so if you are from out of town the barrels are $95 each. 

Sign up for your Rain Barrels now at the Borough Hall or at: http://www.signupgenius.com/go/30e0545afae2ca3fe3-rainbarrel

results.description:
Feeling stressed, unbalanced and need to relax? Meditation is a wonderful antidote to the pervasive stress we are under. Not sure where to start? Take an hour to learn how to slow down and find some calm in your internal world. Studies have shown that practicing meditation changes the brain-- increasing productivity, bringing about greater physical and mental health, reducing stress/anxiety and modulating pain.

Learn more about stress, how it affects your brain and body and how meditation can be the antidote. While there are varying meditation techniques, this hour-long workshop will focus on the breath, sound and mantra meditation. The first 25 minutes will be about stress, meditation and the brain/getting comfortable to sit, followed by 25 minutes of guided meditation using the breath, sound and mantra meditation techniques with periods of silence to practice the techniques. The remainder of the time will be available for comments and questions. You will walk away with techniques that can be integrated into the busiest of schedules.

More information about my background can be found at www.thelongtimesun.org.

***

Location: MNDFL (a meditation studio), 10 East 8th Street, Manhattan.

Date: Sunday, April 24, 2016

Time: 1:30-2:30 pm (please arrive at least 5 minutes before the start)

Attire: We will be sitting on cushions on the floor, so please wear comfortable clothes. There is a no shoe policy at MNDFL, so wear your nicest socks!

RSVP:  Cushions and space will be limited, so RSVP on meet up or email me at [masked] to participate. Please only RSVP if you know you can attend.

Fee: $15 (cash only)

results.description:
WE GOING TO WALK IN CENTRAL PARK. SOME IMPORTANT LOCATION IS MENTIONED HERE TO SEE AROUND THIS WALK;

We meet at 1:45 PM. We wait for everyone until 2:00 PM and then walk start.Please come early so you can meet and greet each other before start walk.

WE MIGHT SEE ALL BEAUTIFUL CHERRY BLOSSOM TREE IN SIDE THE GARDEN AND AROUND RESORVIR.

Conservatory Garden Center Fountain

With its elegant geyser fountain standing before a wrought-iron wisteria pergola, the Italian-designed Center Garden is an enchanting spot. From the steps of Vanderbilt Gate on Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, the sweeping view of the Center Garden's formal green lawn is capped at the far end with this elegant geyser fountain. One of three stylized gardens that make up the six-acre Conservatory Garden, the Center Garden features hallmarks of its classic Italian design, geometric shaped vegetation, and fountains. The Italian garden is a popular site for wedding photography. In spring, its the fitting floral backdrop to the annual Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon of the Conservancy's Women's Committee.

Location

Inside Conservatory Garden, East Side from 104th-106th streets; enter at Fifth Avenue and 105th street, or 106th St. gate inside Park


Conservatory Garden

The Conservatory Garden is Central Park's six-acre formal garden. It is divided into three smaller gardens, each with a distinct style: Italian, French, and English. The Garden's main entrance is through the Vanderbilt Gate, on Fifth Avenue between 104th and 105th Streets. This magnificent iron gate, made in Paris in 1894, originally stood before the Vanderbilt mansion at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street.

The Italianate center garden is composed of a large lawn surrounded by yew hedges and is bordered by two exquisite allées of spring-blooming pink and white crabapple trees. A 12-foot high jet fountain plays on the western end of the lawn, backed by tiered hedges and stairs that lead up to a wisteria pergola. On the walkway under the pergola are medallions inscribed with the names of the original 13 states.

The northern, French-style garden showcases parterres of germander and spectacular seasonal displays of spring tulips, and Korean chrysanthemums in autumn, all within an ellipse of Japanese holly. In the center is the charming Three Dancing Maidens fountain by German sculptor, Walter Schott. To the south is the very intimate English-style garden. There are five mixed borders of trees, shrubs and perennial plants, and five seasonal beds featuring spring bulbs that are followed by annual flower displays. A slope of woodland plants lines the western edge of this garden. At the center is sculptor Bessie Potter Vonnoh's lovely Frances Hodgeson Burnett Memorial Fountain, a tribute to the author of the children's book, The Secret Garden. The children — a girl and a boy, said to depict Mary and Dickon, the main characters from the classic — stand at one end of a small water lily pool. 

The Conservatory Garden is an officially designated Quiet Zone and offers a calm and colorful setting for a leisurely stroll, and intimate wedding, or an escape with a good book.

For many years the garden was tended by volunteers from the Garden Club of America and in 1983 it was restored by the Central Park Conservancy.

Location

East Side from 104th-106th Streets. Enter at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, or 106th Street gate inside the Park.

» Map It

Details

Hours: 8am to dusk

Wheelchair access at 106th St. gate inside Park

Restroom available

Quiet Zone (dogs must be leashed and kept on pathways at all times; no running, rollerblading, or bike riding; no organized, active recreation or sports allowed; headphones required for radios)


North Woods

Perhaps the most secluded and peaceful area of Central Park, the North Woods (located at Central Park's northwest corner) offers a taste of the Adirondack Mountains just a few subway stops away from Times Square.

The North Woods is one of the Park's three woodlands (along with the Ramble and Hallett Nature Sanctuary), offering people and wildlife an oasis of nature in the middle of New York City. The heart of the North Woods is the Ravine. Fallen trees, or snags, are left where they land (unless hazardous or obscuring paths), providing nutrients to surrounding plants, homes to wildlife and a natural look to the landscape.

Once entering through the magnificent rustic Glen Span Arch at the eastern edge of the Pool (between 100th and 103rd Streets), Park visitors are treated to a view of the Loch, a stream rebuilt by the Conservancy in the 1990s. The North Woods is a favorite spot of birdwatchers and hikers. Free guided tours are available regularly. You can learn more about the North Woods, and the Park's other woodlands (the Ramble and the Hallett Nature Sanctuary), through one of our Woodland Discovery Programs.

Location

East Side to Mid-Park from 101nd - 110nd Streets.


Blockhouse

Central Park's oldest building, the Blockhouse is also the only remaining fortification of the many built in 1814 to defend against the British. It stands on the edge of a high precipice above the lower topography of Harlem. The rugged stone structure once had a sunken wooden roof and mobile cannon that could be deployed quickly. Today, the Blockhouse is empty, roofless, and securely locked.

Location

West Side at 109th Street and Central Park West.

Shakespeare Garden

Shakespeare Garden is a four-acre landscape is named for the famed English poet and playwright. The garden is features flowers and plants mentioned in his poems and plays, with small bronze plaques scattered throughout the garden with quotes from the Bard.

The garden was first conceived in the 1880s when park commissioner George Clausen asked the Park's entomologist to create a garden adjacent to the nature study center in the Swedish Cottage. In 1913, Commissioner Gaynor dedicated it officially to the works of Shakespeare. After years of neglect, Shakespeare Garden, just as most of Central Park, fell into disrepair. In 1987, Central Park Conservancy restored and expanded the garden, repaving pathways and installing rustic wooden benches and bronze plaques with quotations from the Bard's masterpiece.

Location

West Side between 79th and 80th Streets.

The Ramble

To use the words of Park designer Frederick Law Olmsted, The Ramble is a 38-acre "wild garden."  Central Park's designers imagined a tranquil spot where visitors could stroll, discover forest gardens rich with plantings, and meander along the paths. This truly is a place for the urban explorer to escape the city and get utterly lost in nature.

This was one of the first parts of the Park to be built, and except for the bedrock platform, it is totally artificial. Even the water running in the stream and the adjacent Lake is turned on and off like a faucet. Some of the trees you see date back to 1859 when the Ramble was planted.

Beneath the leafy canopy, you are surrounded by a thriving wildlife habitat. Because of its location on the Atlantic Flyway — the migration route birds follow in the spring and fall — the Ramble is the center of birding activity in the Park. Over 230 species have been spotted, and over 40 other species remain in the Park all year long.

Every year, more than 25 million people visit Central Park, which is more than any other urban Park in the world. By working with environmental groups, the Central Park Conservancy has developed a woodland restoration and management plan, which involves your participation as well.

First, "carry in, carry out."  All of the trash and recycling bins have been removed from inside the Ramble, and placed at the entrances. If you enjoy a picnic in this beautiful setting, don't forget to take your leftovers with you and dispose of them properly. It's a simple gesture, but it really helps the environment and the Conservancy staff responsible for its care.

Location

Mid-Park from 73rd to 79th Streets.

» Map It

Belvedere Castle

Calvert Vaux, co-designer of Central Park, created the miniature castle in 1869 as one of its many whimsical structures intended as a lookout to the reservoir to the north (now the Great Lawn) and the Ramble to the south. Belvedere provides the best and highest views of the Park and its cityscape. It's fitting, considering its name translates to "beautiful view" in Italian. 

"Right now, the temperature in Central Park is..." Since 1919, the National Weather Service has taken measurements onf New York's weather from the castle's tower with the aid of scientific instruments that measure wind speed and direction. In a fenced-in compound just south of the castle, other data such as the rainfall is recorded and sent to the weather service's forecast office at Brookhaven National Library on Long Island. After decades of deterioration, Central Park Conservancy renovated and reopened the castle in 1983 as a visitor center.

Location

Mid-Park at 79th Street

» Map It

Details

Open Hours:

10am-5pm daily, except Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day

Phone: [masked]

Bethesda Fountain

Rising from Bethesda Terrace is Bethesda Fountain, with the famous Angel of the Waters statue atop. The statue references the Gospel of John, which describes an angel blessing the Pool of Bethesda and giving it healing powers. The fountain commemorates the Croton water system, which first brought fresh water to New York City in 1842. The angel carries a lily in her left hand — a symbol of the water's purity, very important to a city that had previously suffered from a devastating cholera epidemic before the system was established. The piece is the only statue that was commissioned for the Park. Created by Emma Stebbins, it also marked the first time a woman received a public art commission in New York City.


Mid-Park on the north side of 72nd Street

SUBWAY DIRECTION :

WE MIGHT SEE ALL BEAUTIFUL CHERRY BLOSSOM TREE IN SIDE THE GARDEN AND AROUND RESORVIR.

Conservatory Garden Center Fountain

With its elegant geyser fountain standing before a wrought-iron wisteria pergola, the Italian-designed Center Garden is an enchanting spot. From the steps of Vanderbilt Gate on Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, the sweeping view of the Center Garden's formal green lawn is capped at the far end with this elegant geyser fountain. One of three stylized gardens that make up the six-acre Conservatory Garden, the Center Garden features hallmarks of its classic Italian design, geometric shaped vegetation, and fountains. The Italian garden is a popular site for wedding photography. In spring, its the fitting floral backdrop to the annual Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon of the Conservancy's Women's Committee.

Location

Inside Conservatory Garden, East Side from 104th-106th streets; enter at Fifth Avenue and 105th street, or 106th St. gate inside Park


Conservatory Garden

The Conservatory Garden is Central Park's six-acre formal garden. It is divided into three smaller gardens, each with a distinct style: Italian, French, and English. The Garden's main entrance is through the Vanderbilt Gate, on Fifth Avenue between 104th and 105th Streets. This magnificent iron gate, made in Paris in 1894, originally stood before the Vanderbilt mansion at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street.

The Italianate center garden is composed of a large lawn surrounded by yew hedges and is bordered by two exquisite allées of spring-blooming pink and white crabapple trees. A 12-foot high jet fountain plays on the western end of the lawn, backed by tiered hedges and stairs that lead up to a wisteria pergola. On the walkway under the pergola are medallions inscribed with the names of the original 13 states.

The northern, French-style garden showcases parterres of germander and spectacular seasonal displays of spring tulips, and Korean chrysanthemums in autumn, all within an ellipse of Japanese holly. In the center is the charming Three Dancing Maidens fountain by German sculptor, Walter Schott. To the south is the very intimate English-style garden. There are five mixed borders of trees, shrubs and perennial plants, and five seasonal beds featuring spring bulbs that are followed by annual flower displays. A slope of woodland plants lines the western edge of this garden. At the center is sculptor Bessie Potter Vonnoh's lovely Frances Hodgeson Burnett Memorial Fountain, a tribute to the author of the children's book, The Secret Garden. The children — a girl and a boy, said to depict Mary and Dickon, the main characters from the classic — stand at one end of a small water lily pool. 

The Conservatory Garden is an officially designated Quiet Zone and offers a calm and colorful setting for a leisurely stroll, and intimate wedding, or an escape with a good book.

For many years the garden was tended by volunteers from the Garden Club of America and in 1983 it was restored by the Central Park Conservancy.

Location

East Side from 104th-106th Streets. Enter at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, or 106th Street gate inside the Park.

» Map It

Details

Hours: 8am to dusk

Wheelchair access at 106th St. gate inside Park

Restroom available

Quiet Zone (dogs must be leashed and kept on pathways at all times; no running, rollerblading, or bike riding; no organized, active recreation or sports allowed; headphones required for radios)


North Woods

Perhaps the most secluded and peaceful area of Central Park, the North Woods (located at Central Park's northwest corner) offers a taste of the Adirondack Mountains just a few subway stops away from Times Square.

The North Woods is one of the Park's three woodlands (along with the Ramble and Hallett Nature Sanctuary), offering people and wildlife an oasis of nature in the middle of New York City. The heart of the North Woods is the Ravine. Fallen trees, or snags, are left where they land (unless hazardous or obscuring paths), providing nutrients to surrounding plants, homes to wildlife and a natural look to the landscape.

Once entering through the magnificent rustic Glen Span Arch at the eastern edge of the Pool (between 100th and 103rd Streets), Park visitors are treated to a view of the Loch, a stream rebuilt by the Conservancy in the 1990s. The North Woods is a favorite spot of birdwatchers and hikers. Free guided tours are available regularly. You can learn more about the North Woods, and the Park's other woodlands (the Ramble and the Hallett Nature Sanctuary), through one of our Woodland Discovery Programs.

Location

East Side to Mid-Park from 101nd - 110nd Streets.


Blockhouse

Central Park's oldest building, the Blockhouse is also the only remaining fortification of the many built in 1814 to defend against the British. It stands on the edge of a high precipice above the lower topography of Harlem. The rugged stone structure once had a sunken wooden roof and mobile cannon that could be deployed quickly. Today, the Blockhouse is empty, roofless, and securely locked.

Location

West Side at 109th Street and Central Park West.

Shakespeare Garden

Shakespeare Garden is a four-acre landscape is named for the famed English poet and playwright. The garden is features flowers and plants mentioned in his poems and plays, with small bronze plaques scattered throughout the garden with quotes from the Bard.

The garden was first conceived in the 1880s when park commissioner George Clausen asked the Park's entomologist to create a garden adjacent to the nature study center in the Swedish Cottage. In 1913, Commissioner Gaynor dedicated it officially to the works of Shakespeare. After years of neglect, Shakespeare Garden, just as most of Central Park, fell into disrepair. In 1987, Central Park Conservancy restored and expanded the garden, repaving pathways and installing rustic wooden benches and bronze plaques with quotations from the Bard's masterpiece.

Location

West Side between 79th and 80th Streets.

The Ramble

To use the words of Park designer Frederick Law Olmsted, The Ramble is a 38-acre "wild garden."  Central Park's designers imagined a tranquil spot where visitors could stroll, discover forest gardens rich with plantings, and meander along the paths. This truly is a place for the urban explorer to escape the city and get utterly lost in nature.

This was one of the first parts of the Park to be built, and except for the bedrock platform, it is totally artificial. Even the water running in the stream and the adjacent Lake is turned on and off like a faucet. Some of the trees you see date back to 1859 when the Ramble was planted.

Beneath the leafy canopy, you are surrounded by a thriving wildlife habitat. Because of its location on the Atlantic Flyway — the migration route birds follow in the spring and fall — the Ramble is the center of birding activity in the Park. Over 230 species have been spotted, and over 40 other species remain in the Park all year long.

Every year, more than 25 million people visit Central Park, which is more than any other urban Park in the world. By working with environmental groups, the Central Park Conservancy has developed a woodland restoration and management plan, which involves your participation as well.

First, "carry in, carry out."  All of the trash and recycling bins have been removed from inside the Ramble, and placed at the entrances. If you enjoy a picnic in this beautiful setting, don't forget to take your leftovers with you and dispose of them properly. It's a simple gesture, but it really helps the environment and the Conservancy staff responsible for its care.

Location

Mid-Park from 73rd to 79th Streets.

» Map It

Belvedere Castle

Calvert Vaux, co-designer of Central Park, created the miniature castle in 1869 as one of its many whimsical structures intended as a lookout to the reservoir to the north (now the Great Lawn) and the Ramble to the south. Belvedere provides the best and highest views of the Park and its cityscape. It's fitting, considering its name translates to "beautiful view" in Italian. 

"Right now, the temperature in Central Park is..." Since 1919, the National Weather Service has taken measurements onf New York's weather from the castle's tower with the aid of scientific instruments that measure wind speed and direction. In a fenced-in compound just south of the castle, other data such as the rainfall is recorded and sent to the weather service's forecast office at Brookhaven National Library on Long Island. After decades of deterioration, Central Park Conservancy renovated and reopened the castle in 1983 as a visitor center.

Location

Mid-Park at 79th Street

» Map It

Details

Open Hours:

10am-5pm daily, except Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day

Phone: [masked]

Bethesda Fountain

Rising from Bethesda Terrace is Bethesda Fountain, with the famous Angel of the Waters statue atop. The statue references the Gospel of John, which describes an angel blessing the Pool of Bethesda and giving it healing powers. The fountain commemorates the Croton water system, which first brought fresh water to New York City in 1842. The angel carries a lily in her left hand — a symbol of the water's purity, very important to a city that had previously suffered from a devastating cholera epidemic before the system was established. The piece is the only statue that was commissioned for the Park. Created by Emma Stebbins, it also marked the first time a woman received a public art commission in New York City.


Mid-Park on the north side of 72nd Street

TAKE # 6 TO 96 STREET AND WALK TOWARDS TO Madison Ave or Take M 86 bus from there.
