In the center is the charming Three Dancing Maidens fountain by German sculptor, Walter Schott. To the south is the very intimate English-style garden. There are five mixed borders of trees, shrubs and perennial plants, and five seasonal beds featuring spring bulbs that are followed by annual flower displays. A slope of woodland plants lines the western edge of this garden. At the center is sculptor Bessie Potter Vonnoh's lovely Frances Hodgeson Burnett Memorial Fountain, a tribute to the author of the children's book, The Secret Garden. The children — a girl and a boy, said to depict Mary and Dickon, the main characters from the classic — stand at one end of a small water lily pool. 

The Conservatory Garden is an officially designated Quiet Zone and offers a calm and colorful setting for a leisurely stroll, and intimate wedding, or an escape with a good book.

For many years the garden was tended by volunteers from the Garden Club of America and in 1983 it was restored by the Central Park Conservancy.

Location

East Side from 104th-106th Streets. Enter at Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, or 106th Street gate inside the Park.

» Map It

Details

Hours: 8am to dusk

Wheelchair access at 106th St. gate inside Park

Restroom available

Quiet Zone (dogs must be leashed and kept on pathways at all times; no running, rollerblading, or bike riding; no organized, active recreation or sports allowed; headphones required for radios)


North Woods

Perhaps the most secluded and peaceful area of Central Park, the North Woods (located at Central Park's northwest corner) offers a taste of the Adirondack Mountains just a few subway stops away from Times Square.

The North Woods is one of the Park's three woodlands (along with the Ramble and Hallett Nature Sanctuary), offering people and wildlife an oasis of nature in the middle of New York City. The heart of the North Woods is the Ravine. Fallen trees, or snags, are left where they land (unless hazardous or obscuring paths), providing nutrients to surrounding plants, homes to wildlife and a natural look to the landscape.

Once entering through the magnificent rustic Glen Span Arch at the eastern edge of the Pool (between 100th and 103rd Streets), Park visitors are treated to a view of the Loch, a stream rebuilt by the Conservancy in the 1990s. The North Woods is a favorite spot of birdwatchers and hikers. Free guided tours are available regularly. You can learn more about the North Woods, and the Park's other woodlands (the Ramble and the Hallett Nature Sanctuary), through one of our Woodland Discovery Programs.

Location

East Side to Mid-Park from 101nd - 110nd Streets.


Blockhouse

Central Park's oldest building, the Blockhouse is also the only remaining fortification of the many built in 1814 to defend against the British. It stands on the edge of a high precipice above the lower topography of Harlem. The rugged stone structure once had a sunken wooden roof and mobile cannon that could be deployed quickly. Today, the Blockhouse is empty, roofless, and securely locked.

Location

West Side at 109th Street and Central Park West.

Shakespeare Garden

Shakespeare Garden is a four-acre landscape is named for the famed English poet and playwright. The garden is features flowers and plants mentioned in his poems and plays, with small bronze plaques scattered throughout the garden with quotes from the Bard.

The garden was first conceived in the 1880s when park commissioner George Clausen asked the Park's entomologist to create a garden adjacent to the nature study center in the Swedish Cottage. In 1913, Commissioner Gaynor dedicated it officially to the works of Shakespeare. After years of neglect, Shakespeare Garden, just as most of Central Park, fell into disrepair. In 1987, Central Park Conservancy restored and expanded the garden, repaving pathways and installing rustic wooden benches and bronze plaques with quotations from the Bard's masterpiece.

Location

West Side between 79th and 80th Streets.

The Ramble

To use the words of Park designer Frederick Law Olmsted, The Ramble is a 38-acre "wild garden."  Central Park's designers imagined a tranquil spot where visitors could stroll, discover forest gardens rich with plantings, and meander along the paths. This truly is a place for the urban explorer to escape the city and get utterly lost in nature.

This was one of the first parts of the Park to be built, and except for the bedrock platform, it is totally artificial. Even the water running in the stream and the adjacent Lake is turned on and off like a faucet. Some of the trees you see date back to 1859 when the Ramble was planted.

Beneath the leafy canopy, you are surrounded by a thriving wildlife habitat. Because of its location on the Atlantic Flyway — the migration route birds follow in the spring and fall — the Ramble is the center of birding activity in the Park. Over 230 species have been spotted, and over 40 other species remain in the Park all year long.

Every year, more than 25 million people visit Central Park, which is more than any other urban Park in the world. By working with environmental groups, the Central Park Conservancy has developed a woodland restoration and management plan, which involves your participation as well.

First, "carry in, carry out."  All of the trash and recycling bins have been removed from inside the Ramble, and placed at the entrances. If you enjoy a picnic in this beautiful setting, don't forget to take your leftovers with you and dispose of them properly. It's a simple gesture, but it really helps the environment and the Conservancy staff responsible for its care.

Location

Mid-Park from 73rd to 79th Streets.

» Map It

Belvedere Castle

Calvert Vaux, co-designer of Central Park, created the miniature castle in 1869 as one of its many whimsical structures intended as a lookout to the reservoir to the north (now the Great Lawn) and the Ramble to the south. Belvedere provides the best and highest views of the Park and its cityscape. It's fitting, considering its name translates to "beautiful view" in Italian. 

"Right now, the temperature in Central Park is..." Since 1919, the National Weather Service has taken measurements onf New York's weather from the castle's tower with the aid of scientific instruments that measure wind speed and direction. In a fenced-in compound just south of the castle, other data such as the rainfall is recorded and sent to the weather service's forecast office at Brookhaven National Library on Long Island. After decades of deterioration, Central Park Conservancy renovated and reopened the castle in 1983 as a visitor center.

Location

Mid-Park at 79th Street

» Map It

Details

Open Hours:

10am-5pm daily, except Thanksgiving, Christmas Day, and New Year's Day

Phone: [masked]

Bethesda Fountain

Rising from Bethesda Terrace is Bethesda Fountain, with the famous Angel of the Waters statue atop. The statue references the Gospel of John, which describes an angel blessing the Pool of Bethesda and giving it healing powers. The fountain commemorates the Croton water system, which first brought fresh water to New York City in 1842. The angel carries a lily in her left hand — a symbol of the water's purity, very important to a city that had previously suffered from a devastating cholera epidemic before the system was established. The piece is the only statue that was commissioned for the Park. Created by Emma Stebbins, it also marked the first time a woman received a public art commission in New York City.


Mid-Park on the north side of 72nd Street

SUBWAY DIRECTION : 

TAKE # 6 TO 96 STREET AND WALK TOWARDS TO Madison  Ave or Take M 86 bus from there. 


Bus: 

 M-1,M-2,M-3 and M-4 : Madison Ave bus to 96 street . Starbucks in corner.

We meet at 1:45 PM. We wait for everyone until 2:00 PM and then walk start.Please come early so you can meet and greet each other before start walk.

WE MIGHT SEE ALL BEAUTIFUL CHERRY BLOSSOM TREE IN SIDE THE GARDEN AND AROUND RESORVIR.

Conservatory Garden Center Fountain

With its elegant geyser fountain standing before a wrought-iron wisteria pergola, the Italian-designed Center Garden is an enchanting spot. From the steps of Vanderbilt Gate on Fifth Avenue and 105th Street, the sweeping view of the Center Garden's formal green lawn is capped at the far end with this elegant geyser fountain. One of three stylized gardens that make up the six-acre Conservatory Garden, the Center Garden features hallmarks of its classic Italian design, geometric shaped vegetation, and fountains. The Italian garden is a popular site for wedding photography. In spring, its the fitting floral backdrop to the annual Frederick Law Olmsted Awards Luncheon of the Conservancy's Women's Committee.

Location

Inside Conservatory Garden, East Side from 104th-106th streets; enter at Fifth Avenue and 105th street, or 106th St. gate inside Park


Conservatory Garden

The Conservatory Garden is Central Park's six-acre formal garden. It is divided into three smaller gardens, each with a distinct style: Italian, French, and English. The Garden's main entrance is through the Vanderbilt Gate, on Fifth Avenue between 104th and 105th Streets. This magnificent iron gate, made in Paris in 1894, originally stood before the Vanderbilt mansion at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street.

The Italianate center garden is composed of a large lawn surrounded by yew hedges and is bordered by two exquisite allées of spring-blooming pink and white crabapple trees. A 12-foot high jet fountain plays on the western end of the lawn, backed by tiered hedges and stairs that lead up to a wisteria pergola. On the walkway under the pergola are medallions inscribed with the names of the original 13 states.

The northern, French-style garden showcases parterres of germander and spectacular seasonal displays of spring tulips, and Korean chrysanthemums in autumn, all within an ellipse of Japanese holly. results.description:
Join DM Evan Lonergan in his encore presentation of Brotherhood of the Phoenix: Spires of the Embershade, his adventure for six 3rd level characters. Evan has been playing D&D at Wildpig since we started running RPGs, and his game was so popular among players that we're bringing it back for another round.

Welcome to the Brotherhood of the Phoenix: the most powerful adventuring guild in all of Aria! You're about to embark on your first job as initiates. A village near the Embershade Mountains has reported goblins attacking and kidnapping their villagers, and has asked the Brotherhood for help. Will your first job with the Brotherhood turn out to be as simple as it seems?

results.description:
Join Outdoor Afro for a picturesque stroll at the park! Sunday April 24th from 2:00-4:00p we will celebrate The 30th annual Cherry Blossom Festival in Newark's own Branch Brook Park. This collection of trees is one of the most stunning in the country and the world. We will tour the park for this nature photography event. No special camera or experience is necessary for this casual occasion, you can use your phone or just come along for the stroll! We will be walking however, so comfortable shoes are a must! See you soon as we view newark through a new lens!

This event is easily accessible via public transportation. Please note that we're going to meet at the park entrance near the corner of Lake Street & Park Avenue ACROSS the street from 199 Lake Street. The Cherry Blossoms went off early this year but there's still a few left to enjoy and the park itself is beautiful! See you all soon! We'll be strolling for 2 miles. Remember to bring at Least 24oz of water! See you on the trail!
results.name: Outdoor Afro Cherry Blossom Photography

results.description:
TICKETS ON OUR SITE


---------------------------------------
Please note that you must have a ticket from Eventbrite (purchased through our site) to attend.


RSVP'ing on Meetup alone will not get you in.

“The aim of Art is to present not the outward appearance of things, but their inner significance; for this, not the external manner and detail, constitutes true reality.” -- Aristotle

The root of portrait can be found from prehistoric times. In the ancient past, portrait paintings have primarily memorialized the rich and powerful. Over time, however, it became more common for middle-class patrons to commission portraits of their families and colleagues. What role does portrait painting play in the modern world, which is overwhelmed by easy and low-cost photography? What are the processes and techniques modern portraitists use to paint? How should we look at and analyze a portrait?

In this event, Raina Dai, a New York based portraitist, will help us to understand all these qustions, and share her passion in the making of arts with us. Wine and refreshments will be served.
results.name: Portrait from Life -Artist Guided Studio Tour & Live Portrait Painting

Get together to meet new people, and share works with each others for enjoyment and critique, and share ideas.


While you're at it, also be sure to check out our Facebook group at https://www.facebook.com/groups/1694416874177214/ and feel free to ask to join.

—————

Artist Guided Studio Tour & Live Portrait Painting


Portrait from Life 

“The aim of Art is to present not the outward appearance of things, but their inner significance; for this, not the external manner and detail, constitutes true reality.” -- Aristotle

The root of portrait can be found from prehistoric times. In the ancient past, portrait paintings have primarily memorialized the rich and powerful. Over time, however, it became more common for middle-class patrons to commission portraits of their families and colleagues. What role does portrait painting play in the modern world, which is overwhelmed by easy and low-cost photography? What are the processes and techniques modern portraitists use to paint? How should we look at and analyze a portrait?

In this event, Raina Dai, a New York based portraitist, will help us to understand all these questions, and share her passion in the making of art with us. Wine and refreshments will be served.

results.description:
IMPORTANT: RSVP UPDATE - REQUIRED AND REQUESTED:

Greetings!

PLEASE NOTE:

If you HAVE ALREADY RSVPd "YES" for our April 24th musicale, please re-confirm by tomorrow, Monday, April 18. Just send me an email saying you will definitely be coming. If you have doubts about attending, or have definitely decided you cannot make it,  kindly change your RSVP to "NO..

RSVP for April 24 has been extended to Friday, April 23, due to recent interest in our event by members and friends. If you HAVE NOT YET RSVPd for the musicale, please do so by April 23 at 10:00 p.m., at the latest, on our website posting. Send me an email with your confirmation and let me know what you are bringing to the potluck. Thanks. You may bring a friend of two whom you should include in your RSVP.

YOUR RSVPs are very important to us. Be sure that you can still attend this event before re-confirming "yes". Since we hire a pianist for these events, we must be certain we have enough people attending so we can cover his expenses. His schedule is extremely tight, and we need to be considerate of his time. 

FYI: We still have room on the program for 1-2 performers. If you would like to perform, please email me and RSVP for our upcoming workshop this coming Tuesday, April 19, at 6:00 p.m. so we can work on your songs and/or monologues.

 If I haven't worked with you, previously, the workshop is mandatory. If I have, just let me know what you would like to perform, and come to the workshop, if at all possible. And, be sure to bring your songs in sheet music form on the 24th. Lead sheets are acceptable.

RSVPs tend to change, often, with each passing day, which can affect event scheduling, so we thank you for your cooperation!

We look forward to seeing you on April 24th, and to enjoying songs sung by STSANY members, Hayley Adkisson and Christine Petit. Listen to Christine at: https://soundcloud.com/christinepetitmusic


Read details below.

Dear STSANY MEMBERS and FRIENDS:


SAVE THE DATE!

Once again, I am pleased to invite you and your friends and family to attend our  Music & Drama on Sundays: Informal Musicale and Potluck Buffet on Sunday, April 24, from 2:00-5:00 p.m. (Friendly, sweet Trixie the Cat is on the premises!)

Our accompanist for the afternoon will be Eric Sedgwick, an accomplished pianist based in New York City, who has played for several STSANY events.

Contribution: $15 - in cash at the door - to pay our accompanist and donate to STSANY's operating costs. 

NOTE: The entertainment will start promptly at 2:30 p.m., so please arrive by 2, at the latest, to get a seat. RSVP-ASAP as seating is limited (about 20 seats + a few). Don't wait until the RSVP deadline, which is Friday, April 22 at 10 p.m. 

Watch this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DGTP21ZtqtQ: Spanish singer, Cristina Ramos, proves that we are capable of doing absolutely anything as performers, if we go a little out of the box, sometimes! Any comments?


POTLUCK BUFFET:  Please let me know what you'll bring when you RSVP.

Welcome contributions would include:

Drinks: Wine, Juice, Sparkling Cider/Water, etc.

Nibbles, i.e.: Appetizers, Cheese/Crackers/Bread; Dumplings; Hummus;  Chips/Dips; Raw Veggies and Fruits (cut up); Cookies and other small sweet things

NOTE: SINGERS, SINGER-SONGWRITERS, ACTORS & INSTRUMENTALISTS  may perform if:

• They have attended workshops, performed in STSANY musicals, etc., and/or have participated in volunteer events during 2015 to the present;

• They are new members and attend at least one workshop between now and April 24;


• They are invited by STSANY organizers.

Each person will be given 3-5 minutes to perform. Kindly contact me with the name of your song(s) and monologue(s) and their length. Singers must bring complete sheet music in the key in which you will sing for our pianist - no lead sheets, chord sheets or requests to transpose, please.

Our diverse program has something for everybody: Classical, jazz, pop, musical theatre, etc., selections, and both comedic and dramatic monologues, stories, etc.

WHAT IS A MUSICALE?

In the salon tradition of yore, going back thousands (O.K., hundreds) of years, we shall gather together, bring a friend, enjoy each other's company, sing a song, play the piano, etc., fiddle a fiddle, do a monologue, recite a poem or tell a story (funny or otherwise), or balance a ballon on our heads! Let me know if you would like to perform.* 

Afterward we shall revel in a ridiculously delicious repast brought by us all: Appetizers, wine, non-alcoholic drinks, desserts, fruit, cheese, crackers, dumplings, macaroni and cheese or duck a l'orange, if you feel ambitious. Who am I to say no to that? Please tell me what you are bringing and the number of guests when you RSVP.

I look forward to seeing you on April 24 and at our future meetups! Be sure to check the postings on "Upcoming Meetups."

Cheers,

Anna Bartos, Founder, Organizer and Artistic Director of STSANY  
A Non-Profit Arts Collective for Singers, Actors and Instrumentalists of All Ages and Levels

www.annabartos.com

NOTE: TO LEARN ABOUT STSANY's GOALS, PLEASE READ"PAGES" in the browser above. Be sure to check out our reviews and past meetups to know what we've been doing! Click on"MORE" and "files" to see flyers for our events, etc. To see our photo albums, click on "PHOTOS" in our browser.

To see and hear members perform, please VISIT our youtube channel: 
http://www.youtube.com/user/AlmaMusica

results.description:

We'll have equipment for some infield practice, throwing, tee work/soft toss, talking about the Mets - whatever you're interesting in to enjoy the game we love. results.description:
Central Park is more than just a pretty face. It was designed to reflect the deep spiritual and political aspirations of the mid-nineteenth century -- a movement called Romanticism, and it is a philosophy that we still embrace today. On this walk, we’ll explore the idealism that continues to embody the Park and the forgotten meanings behind many of its most favorite sites. For example, did you know there is a gothic cathedral hidden in plain sight in one of the most popular sections of the Park?  We'll start our walk at the front entrance of Tavern on the Green, walk through the Sheep Meadow, up the Mall to Bethesda Fountain, around the Lake to Bow Bridge, and end at Belvedere Castle.  


This is a free meet-up and is limited to 20 people.
results.how_to_find_us: Front entrance of Tavern on the Green
results.name: Explore the Romantic Park

results.description:
Eric Asimov, wine critic for The New York Times, has been running a monthly wine "school" column for the newspaper's readers. He selects a region, does a little write-up, and identifies three wines to try. After drinking the wines, people go to the newspaper's on-line comments section to have a conversation about what they've learned and liked. I've had fun doing this for several months, but thought it might be even better with some of you. Let's meet together from time to time, to drink and talk!

The point of this group is to teach and learn from each other.  All levels are welcome, though we do want participation in tasting and discussing the wines from all.  We keep the group small so we can focus on the wines!  Good behavior is a must, as we will be meeting in a private residence.


April details:  We'll be drinking Riesling from Austria this month. Click here to see which wines we will be drinking! Please indicate in the comments section or by emailing me which wine you plan to bring.  This helps us have a variety of bottles.


What to bring: Each participant will be expected to read Asimov's monthly wine write-up and bring one bottle of wine recommended in the article. He generally identifies three specific bottles, and also lists alternates if the three are not available. I find snooth.com and wine-searcher.com helpful in figuring out which wine shops might have the bottle you are looking for.   Please make every effort to find the specific bottles listed by Asimov. Be sure to post a comment with which wine you will be bringing so that we can have a variety of bottles. Some bottle duplication is fine when our group is large, but we don't want all the same bottle. 

Because wine needs food, each participant should also bring something tasty to eat and share. 

RSVP and Waitlist:  If the Meetup is full, you will be offered the option of placing your name on a Waitlist.  Be aware that the Meetup platform will automatically change your RSVP from "Waitlist" and "Yes" if a spot opens. The expectation is that you will monitor your status on the Waitlist, and remove your name if you no longer want to attend.  

Cost:  The cost of the Asimov Wine School meetups will vary depending on the cost of that month's wine.  Generally it's been somewhere between $15-$70 for the bottle you bring plus the cost of whatever snack you select to share.
results.how_to_find_us: The address will be sent to attendees near date of event

results.description:
About United Nations International Mother Earth Day …The word ‘mother’ holds great power. It evokes memories of the women who gave us life, nurtured us as infants and helped mould us into who we are today. The Earth is the ultimate mother – an astounding planet that has, since time immemorial, supported life in myriad forms. As humans, we outgrow the need for constant maternal care. But we can never outgrow our reliance on Mother Earth. As long as we live, we need air, water, fertile soil and the countless other gifts this planet bestows….
…But the big decisions that lie ahead are not just for world leaders and policy-makers. Today, on Mother Earth Day, I ask each one of us to be mindful of the impacts our choices have on this planet, and what those impacts will mean for future generations… " UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon

So please join the celebration while promoting our mother earth

Program Features
• Multicultural music, dance and other activities
• Ringing the peace bell
• Holding multinational flag around the unisphere

Please RSVP (Optional) @ WWW.UNAQUEENS.ORG (It helps us to arrange food & chairs)

Free admission & refreshment


Dance performances are sponsored by


Polish Wianek folk dance

“Our mission is to preserve rich Polish heritage and traditions. We strive to promote and stimulate interest in Polish culture through presentation of authentic Polish dances and songs, as well as through participation in Polish cultural events and activities, and through the display of our programs at other nations public events and activities…” (http://wianek.org)

Bangladesh Academy of Performing Arts

“Bangladesh Academy of Fine Arts, BAFA, is a South Asian Cultural institution which facilitates enrichment in the performing arts. BAFA specializes in the dance forms of Kathak, Folk, and Bangladeshi modern contemporary. Kathak is a classical genre of dance which originated in Northern India and is well known for its intricate choreography, sharp and graceful movements, and compelling footwork. Bangladesh Academy of Fine Arts, BAFA, embraces the heritage and highlight of Bangladeshi culture with the colorful emotions of folk music. BAFA’s mission is to educate and spread the knowledge of the rich artistic background we are truly grateful for…”( Source: http://www.bangladeshcircle.com/bangladesh-business-directory/1402/bangladesh-academy-of-fine-arts-inc/) (BAFA Official Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Bangladesh-Academy-of-Fine-Arts-347975755306533/?fref=ts )

Xochipilli Dance Ensemble (Aztec Dance)

“Xochipilli Dance Ensemble was founded in 2014 to promote Mexican culture through its diverse folk dance styles. Our aim is to blur the generational and geographical boundaries which characterize Mexican folk dance by presenting traditionally celebrated dances along new and original work.”  (http://www.xochipillinyc.com )

La Fraternidad Cultural Incallajta New York (Inca Dance)

“Fraternidad Cultural Incallajta New York, Inc. is a nonprofit organization … Incallajta New York’s primary purpose is the dissemination of the ancestral culture and indigenous traditions of all aspects of the cultural heritage of the ancient Inca Empire while striving to maintain and preserve accuracy in time and history of our country Bolivia.” (http://www.incallajtany.com )

Fraternidad Folklorica y Cultural Caporales Universitarios San Simón

“Fraternidad Folklorica y Cultural Caporales Universitarios San Simón was founded in Cochabamba, Bolivia on November 22, 1978 by a group of residents from Oruro, Bolivia, alumni of the “Universidad Mayor de San Simón”, for the purpose of retaining and growing its ancient customs. This group of youths decided to create a dance group of Caporales as a means to demonstrate their devotion to the Virgin Mary of the Socavón as well as to be able to participate in the Carnival of Oruro.” (http://www.caporalessansimonny.com )
ABOUT UNAUSA-QUEENS
The UNA USA Queens Chapter is a 501(C)3 organization funded by membership dues and donations. We have no staff or offices. The Directors of the Board and committee members from the membership perform all tasks and functions related to our mission. The mission of UNA-USA, a program of the UNF, is to inform, inspire, and mobilize Americans to support the principles and vital work of the United Nations, and to strengthen the United Nations system.
results.name: 8th Annual UNA-USA Earth Day Celebration

results.description:
Here is a Great Chance to Enjoy Katy Wong  For Free

The concert is titled 47 Strings - a program composed of harp music and its evolution from ancient Egypt to modern day. Selections will include works by notable harp composers such as Salzedo and Grandjany, pieces transcribed for the harp, and traditional Celtic music. By performing a variety of genres, I will demonstrate the contrasting sounds produced by the harp. As a matter of fact, I performed with Katy Perry last fall so I will be including a few pop songs, of my own arrangements. 

Katy joined the Off-Broadway musical, The Fantasticks, on harp at the Forestburgh Playhouse in upstate New York. Katy's experiences also include performing at weddings, bridal showers, galas, fundraisers and more. In 2012, Katy had the privilege of performing at the evening gala of Republican politician, Charlotte Vandervalk, in honor of her service. 

Katy Perry and Katy Wong brought New York City’s Fashion Week to a close last night with amini-set at the Harper’s Bazaar September Issue party, her first major performance since February’s headlining Super Bowl slot. Reworking hits such as a harp-driven “Roar,” a trappy “Teenage Dream,” and a much synthier”I Kissed A Girl”  Perry brought drama and high-fashion to the proceedings. Watch footage of her captivating set below — it’s always neat to see a star on Perry’s level rework and remold her classics in ways that makes total sense.

https://youtu.be/cEkWa3ppa2g


Other venues at which Katy has performed include The Rockefeller Center, The Plaza Hotel, Church of Heavenly Rest, and Garrison Church.

through her studies, Katy has traveled internationally to perform with prestigious orchestras. Last summer, Katy joined the 2015 National Youth Orchestra of the United States of America on their first Asia tour - a seven city concert series across China. In 2014, she was selected to perform at the World Harp Congress in Sydney, Australia on behalf of the Focus on Youth Committee.

Last year, Katy premiered Human Songs and Stories by Daniel Bernard as the featured soloist with NYC Face the Music ensemble of the Kaufman Music Center. Katy has also been a guest harpist for many orchestras including the NJCU Symphony of Winds & Percussion, Bloomfield Wind Ensemble, and NYC Face the Music.

Her performances at Carnegie Hall's Stern Auditorium, Lincoln Center's David Geffen Hall, and the United Palace Theatre have won her recognitions such as 1st place in the Emerging Artists Division of the International Young Artist's Harp Competition and 4th in the New Artists Divison.

Katy currently studies and resides at The Juilliard School in New York, NY.

http://www.katywong.com/ 

Music Live Here 


Come Early for Seats- 

Show starts 2:00pm

Enjoy the Serenity, Peace and Love,


Robert

results.description:
PLEASE READ THE INFORMATION BELOW CAREFULLY, ESPECIALLY THE BOLD TYPE.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". THERE IS NO NEED TO POST WHY YOU CAN'T MAKE THE EVENT. 

This is a sociable walk along a very scenic route filled with interesting places. I will occasionally comment on some things (the architecture and social history of buildings) along the way, but you will have plenty of time to socialize with others. We will, once in a while, stop at points of interest. This walk is about 5 miles and moderate paced. 

IF YOU CAN'T KEEP UP WITH A FIVE-MILE, MODERATE PACED WALK WITH SOME UPS AND DOWNS, THEN THIS WALK IS NOT GOOD FOR YOU.

If you have any questions for me, please contact me through my private Meetup inbox. The organizer for this Meetup event is John (the Event Host) who is listed on the top of the "going list" with a photo. 

Description: We’ll first explore the seldom-traveled Manhattan Valley Historic District and then go to picturesque Hamilton Heights. We will go past the Neo-Gothic City College; several historic districts; a church made from recycled materials; an adaptive reuse building with an uneasy past; a nowadays real estate holdout; and a remnant from the 1960s college student protests. We'll also look at and discuss various sculptures: mythical griffins, unbeloved statues, comical grotesques, and monstrous gargoyles. 

Cost: The cost of this event is $2 per person, which is paid at the start of the walk. This is for the organizer’s Meetup preparation costs and fees.

Meeting Time/Place: The meeting time is (after lunch) at 2:00 PM.  The meeting place is in front of the entrance to Whole Foods Market, 808 Columbus Avenue, which is located at about 98th Street. Before the walk, restrooms are available in Whole Foods Market. During the walk we'll also stop for restrooms in one or two places.

Transportation: Take the 1, 2, or 3 subway train to 96th Street and then walk east about 4 blocks to Whole Foods Market.

Finishing Time: The walk will end about 5:00 PM.

Finishing Place: The walk will finish at 150th Street and Edgecombe Avenue.  At that point, you can catch the No. 1 subway train at 145th and Broadway or the A or D subway trains at 145th and St. Nicholas Avenue.

According to the MTA website, the No. 1 subway train is running this weekend at 145th Street and Broadway. The A or D subway trains are also running this weekend at 145th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.

Rainy weather or other bad weather conditions will cancel this walk. Therefore, if it is rainy weather or other bad weather conditions or the forecast is for rainy weather or other bad weather conditions, I will post a cancellation notice on Sunday morning (before 10:30 AM). If I don't post a cancellation notice, I plan to be at the meeting place. If I do cancel the walk, I will also post a cancellation notice on the Discussion Board.  


Below are some of the many beautiful houses that we will see in these neighborhoods.

Below are some of the many sculptures that we'll be seeing along the way. (Photos The New York Times)
results.name: Historic Manhattan Valley to Hamilton Heights Walk (Apr 24)

group.name: NYC/NJ Walks: Explore Architecture, Art, History & Sculpture

results.description:
Please join us as we discuss "Modern Romance" by Aziz Ansari. Please come with a point of view, a spirit of fellow, and an open mind. As always, I look forward to seeing you there!

Christina

***Book Synopsis***

At some point, every one of us embarks on a journey to find love. We meet people, date, get into and out of relationships, all with the hope of finding someone with whom we share a deep connection. This seems standard now, but it’s wildly different from what people did even just decades ago. Single people today have more romantic options than at any point in human history. With technology, our abilities to connect with and sort through these options are staggering. So why are so many people frustrated?

Some of our problems are unique to our time. “Why did this guy just text me an emoji of a pizza?” “Should I go out with this girl even though she listed Combos as one of her favorite snack foods? Combos?!” “My girlfriend just got a message from some dude named Nathan. Who’s Nathan? Did he just send her a photo of his penis? Should I check just to be sure?” 

But the transformation of our romantic lives can’t be explained by technology alone. In a short period of time, the whole culture of finding love has changed dramatically. A few decades ago, people would find a decent person who lived in their neighborhood. Their families would meet and, after deciding neither party seemed like a murderer, they would get married and soon have a kid, all by the time they were twenty-four. Today, people marry later than ever and spend years of their lives on a quest to find the perfect person, a soul mate.

For years, Aziz Ansari has been aiming his comic insight at modern romance, but forModern Romance, the book, he decided he needed to take things to another level. He teamed up with NYU sociologist Eric Klinenberg and designed a massive research project, including hundreds of interviews and focus groups conducted everywhere from Tokyo to Buenos Aires to Wichita. They analyzed behavioral data and surveys and created their own online research forum on Reddit, which drew thousands of messages. They enlisted the world’s leading social scientists, including Andrew Cherlin, Eli Finkel, Helen Fisher, Sheena Iyengar, Barry Schwartz, Sherry Turkle, and Robb Willer. The result is unlike any social science or humor book we’ve seen before.

In Modern Romance, Ansari combines his irreverent humor with cutting-edge social science to give us an unforgettable tour of our new romantic world.

***Where to Find the Book***

Amazon

Barnes & Noble

Brooklyn Public Library

East Orange Public Library

Hue-Man Bookstore

New York Public Library

Newark Public Library

Queens Library

Sisters Uptown Bookstore


The Strand Bookstore
results.name: "Modern Romance" by Aziz Ansari

results.name: Painting Social (Learn To Paint & Make Friends!) Prepay Only

results.description:
Why just paint when you can Tipsy Paint? That's what we thought too! So put a brush in one hand and a drink in the other (doesn't have to be alcohol) and join us for a unique, colorful way to spend the night out and make new friends!

Tipsy Painting is a step-by-step, group-oriented painting instruction, which is designed to simultaneously entertain and enlighten our members. A professional artist guides you through a featured painting that is yours to keep and proudly display at the end of the night. And don’t worry — no experience is necessary. 

PREPAY ONLY. MUST BUY IN ADVANCE (Space is limited).

*GET TICKET HERE - https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/painting/dates/Apr-24-2016_at_0230PM

$15 food/drink minimum required (doesn't have to be alcholic drinks) Drink specials include two cans of beer / or two glasses house wine for $15 (Price includes tax & tip)

*$35-$45, price goes up as the event date gets closer. This event will sell out, especially for women. Tickets not sold at the door.  

What's included: 

• 2+ hour course lead by an expert artist to teach you the art of mixing colors, blending and painting techniques. 

• 12x16 pre-sketched canvas, acrylic paint (water based), and all painting supplies (brushes, aprons, easels) supplied

• Drink & Food Specials (2 drink min, can be non-alcoholic)  

 • Great Music At Right Volume For Mingling 

• Free Raffle & Prizes 

*Get Tickets At This Link (no door sales) -https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/painting/dates/Apr-24-2016_at_0230PM

*This event sells out quickly so don't wait to get your ticket!

This event is being co-organized by several other groups. The # of RSVP's here are not reflective of actual attendance. Based on presales, at least 25 members will be attending! 

Can I still attend If I don't know how to paint? Yes, there's no experience necessary. 

Can I come alone? Yes, about 80% come on their own. 

Is this age/ethnic/age specific? No, this event is not meant to be age/ethnic specific or gender balanced. All are welcome, 21+. 

How do I attend? RSVP w/ group and purchase ticket here - 

https://dljparty.ticketleap.com/painting/dates/Apr-24-2016_at_0230PM 

This will be the picture we'll be painting -

results.description:
No preparation needed for this meeting! Just bring up to 1,500 words of writing—a flash piece or an excerpt from a longer piece you are working on or the outline of an idea that you need help with. People are encouraged to bring work generated through Writing Room exercises.

The format works like this:

Each writer gets a total of up to 30 minutes, which begins when they read their piece aloud or give a pitch of their idea in five minutes or less. We will be able to do 4 or 5 pieces/ideas per meeting. Names will be drawn at random. (Anyone whose work is not chosen will get priority at the next meeting.) You don’t need to bring work to attend and no advance preparation is required.

Please feel free to bring drinks or snacks. Arielle has power strips to plug in and space to write at both a table and on couches and chairs. Also, there are two cats, in case anyone has allergies.

See you there!

results.description:
This is a weekly introductory improv class taught Sundays from 3-5pm.

-- Are you a bit shy and looking to get more comfortable with your public speaking? 

-- Are you a working professional hoping to be a bit more spontaneous during your meetings and interactions with co-workers? 

-- Or are you an actor or improv comedian looking to take your craft to the next level or get more reps?

Then this is the class for you! In this class, you will learn the fundamentals of scene work (role playing). You'll be on your feet quite a bit as I'm believer that you learn (and have more fun) through doing rather than hearing an instructor talk. Brief individual notes will be given, if that's what you're looking for, and tailored to your level of experience. At the end of each class, I'm confident you'll feel a sense of accomplishment that will leave you more energized and excited to tackle the challenges of everyday life, whether at your work place or in your personal life. 

This class is $10.  If money is an issue for you, let me know and we can work something out.  The cost goes to pay for the cost of the room rental, Meetup fees, and website.  

Hope to see you there!


Steve

www.improvnow.com

www.facebook.com/improvnow

Steve Ling is an alumnus of the improv programs of the Upright Citizens Brigade, Peoples Improv Theater, Magnet Theater, & Annoyance Theater. He regularly produces and performs improv, musical improv, & hip hop improv across NYC.

results.description:
Join us at the park to play acoustic guitar and sing. We play a mix of contemporary, rock, alternative, pop and R&B music, as well as some great songs for female vocalists. We usually play in small groups of  5 – 15 players so that everyone can participate and contribute.  The group is very friendly and casual.

Song lists are posted on our group’s Meetup site.    Log onto the Meetup site and navigate to the 'More' menu and click on the 'Files' tab to view and download the songs.  Be sure to check them out and practice some songs.

Bring your capo, a guitar strap, and a good attitude.  Bring a music stand if you have one, and printed out song book if you can.  There are no dues, but everyone is encouraged to please bring some healthy food, snacks or drinks to share.

The Meetup will be canceled if there is rain, so check the web site on bad weather days for updates.

results.name: WALLYBALL

results.description:
Many of us strive for peace of mind. But what can bring it about? What can restore it when we lose it? And what can make it more likely to be maintained?

In this meetup, we will continue our year of Seneca by exploring his answers to these questions and more in "On Tranquility of Mind" (De Tranquillitate Animi). This text both serves as a fairly good introduction to some aspects of Stoicism while also offering quite a bit to those who are more familiar with Stoicism's basic tenets; both beginners and people more familiar with Stoicism may benefit from this meetup.

To prepare for the meetup, please read the text in full. Also, come prepared with at least one concept or passage you would like to discuss in more detail. Finally, please take note of any practices or concepts that Seneca mentions in this text that would be useful to a modern Stoic. 

While you are welcome to use any translation you'd like, there is a quite good translation available from Wikisource for free.
results.name: On Tranquility of Mind (De Tranquillitate Animi)

results.description:
****READ THIS FIRST || Parade Grounds Game Standards ****

Meet on field 8!!!

The game is scheduled to start at 3:30. We typically start 15-30 minutes after 3:30. Your RSVP is good if you come on time. If you come after teams are divided then you run the risk of not playing. Those who have RSVP’ed get first preference to play (This does not apply to anyone on the waiting list). Also, please  Un-RSVP if you will not be attending. That gives other people a chance to play.

Rules and guidelines:

These games are geared towards advanced to intermediate players.

Teams are divided by two team captains (captains pick players in turns in an attempt to keep teams balanced and competitive)

Physical play is allowed as long as it isn't overly aggressive or dirty.

Slide tackles are allowed only to block a shot on goal or to intercept a pass  NO slide tackling on a player with the ball.

Ball hogging is absolutely not tolerated 

Keep in mind as we don't have permit, we need to be flexible.
results.name: Sunday Pick-up Parade Grounds 3:30 PM

results.description:
NON-COMPETITIVE CO-ED SOCCER GAMES @ Frederick Douglass Playground


                                 Check our Facebook page:

              facebook.com/ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer 

                          NO CLEATS OR PLASTIC STUDS ALLOWED

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=41MNlrZf-MY

GAME DESCRIPTION:

Our games are for all levels and people that prefer to play a non-competitive game of soccer, break a sweat while exercising running up and down the field with the ball and all this happening in a very laid-back and non-judgmental environment. Please, arrive 10 minutes before the game so we can get the teams set up.

Game Format:

We'll play three simultaneous games of 7 on 7, with small goals. There will be 6 teams on the field and we will play three games, 30 minutes/game. Every 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play against different team. Please check our meetup message board on Saturday night or before 9:00 am on Sunday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

RULES OF THE GAME:

1-First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field!

2-Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.

3-No power shots allowed.

4-If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.

5-If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.


6-Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game.

Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Please check our meetup message board on Saturday night or before 12:00 PM on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

Location:

Frederick Douglass Playground


Take the 1,2 or 3 RED Line Train to 96th street Station and walk 4 blocks down, to 101st Street and Amsterdam Ave. or the 1 RED Line Train to 103rd Street Station and walk 1 block.

Call me if you can’t find the field - [masked] Manny S. 

What to bring with you:

A pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes(No CLEATS), shin guards (recommended) and lots of water. There is a water fountain next to the park if you need extra water.

Fee:

You will be asked to pay $9.50 when you RSVP. This $9.50 is used to pay for, facilities permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, goals, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:

Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled. The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.

After the game we'll head to Royale for brunch and a Pint or Two:

                                       Lion’s Head Tavern 

                                     995 Amsterdam Ave

                                      New York, NY 10025

                                           (212)[masked]

PARTICIPATING IN MANHATTAN-INTERNATIONAL-COED-SOCCER ACTIVITIES AGREEMENT:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer programs or activities. Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and its Assistant Organizers reserve the right to take and utilize photographs, video, or any type of recording of participating person while engaged in our or associated activities. I consent to Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer use the photograph, video, or recording of me, for advertising, promotional, or related purposes, and waive all rights to compensation and other rights which may arise as a result.

results.description:
Join us for our very first meetup! 

I am offering a free 1-hour Group Theta Healing session for all my fellow Resonators. This is the first time I am performing a session for a group so I am super excited! Please come in comfy clothes, and bring a yoga mat!

What is Theta Sound Healing?

• This specific type of Sound Therapy utilizes Theta Wave music for brainwave entrainment. In other words, the music played during this session will help you effortlessly settle into a Theta brain wave pattern. The theta wave is a natural brain wave state that is observed during extreme relaxation and during part of the sleeping cycle that induces self-healing. To learn more about Sound Therapy, visit: Alektrik Crystals - Sound Therapy 


Benefits of Theta Sound Healing:

• Through the principle of entrainment, it is possible to use sound to bring the body back into harmony- to not only promote relaxation, but relieve ailments, from common to complex. 

• Sound Therapy, in general, is a great way to help clear unwanted, stagnant, or negative energy blocks from your bio-energy field. These blocks can also manifest as mental, emotional or physical ailments, so maintaining a healthy energetic balance can be a saving grace for many.

What to Expect:

• I will guide you through a meditation for the first few minutes. 

• I will then stay quiet and let the Theta Wave music do it's job. 

• While the rest of the track plays, I will go around the room with my Tuning Fork to manually clear any really stubborn blocks from individual bio-energy fields. The amount of time I spend here depends on the amount of people that attend our first meetup!

So, get ready for a super relaxing and rejuvenating healing experience! Here's to Vibrating Higher! 

(donations for this session will be graciously accepted!)
results.name: Group Theta Healing Session!

group.name: NYC Vibrate Higher Metaphysical Meetup Group

results.description:
We all know the saying: "You never get a second chance to make a first impression."

Although we often forget it, it's absolutely true. Our first impression sets the tone for how others see us. And it determines the authority, influence, credibility or attractiveness we will have with a new person, or in a new environment.

This will be a simple workshop for practicing body language, eye contact, and other key verbal and nonverbal principles that determine your first impression.

I will be leading the workshop with simple techniques and exercises that are inspired by my work with clients.

Ripley-Grier Studios

520 Eighth Avenue

Room 16H

See you there!

Justin

http://JustinAttraction.com

http://NaturalAttractionNYC.com
results.how_to_find_us: Room 16H
results.name: Mastering the First Impression: Free Workshop

results.description:
This is a class in technique although, when you've conquered a song technically, then I will coach musicality and performance. Class size is limited. Fee is $20/per. You may audit the class once for $10. Let me know when you sign up if that's your intention.

Room assignment will be printed on the electronic billboard opposite the elevators on floor 16.

People at the front desk are helpful and friendly and the Cafe on the floor has great latte and cookies, sandwiches, <a>pizza</a>, etc.

I've been asked to post this:


Dear Members:  I am Mr. Harrington's agent/rep. Mr. Harrington teaches privately coaching established actors and singers. For years his private rate has been $120/hr for this service. He started teaching through Meetup earlier this year and has as his goal to bring professional level instruction to the public at a rate that leaves no one behind. This demands tight scheduling of both his time and the room rental with Ripley-Grier Studios.For these reasons, I will be insisting to him that "no shows" be dropped from the group. The policy is this: If you RSVP you better show up. If you cancel you better do this by 4:00 pm the previous day.A word to the wise...Michael T. Harvey

results.description:
RC85-Version Purple Play Day - Fun & Games MeetUp!...


Welcome back Fun Gamers!

First, thank you all for joining our MeetUp Group, "Fun & Games".  

[[ NOTE -- 

Prince was a one of a kind Artist...  irrespective of genre, artists could recognize his talent in every aspect.  So let's celebrate like it's 1999 this Sunday!

Let's have a Purple Play Day!  Everyone wear purple somewhere / somehow!

I'll give something away, I'm not sure what; but the most outrageous Prince costume will definitely get something!...  and if you just wear purple... shirt, pants, shoes, something else more provocatively prince, you'll have the chance to win something else!

Also, maybe we'll all go Karaoke after!!!

-- NOTE ]]

Come & have some fun!!!

I look forward to seeing you all there!...

FYI for the new meeples, we're averaging a solid 20 ppl per week now (just not everyone RSVPs...)  Speaking of RSVPs, I know MeetUp has a cut-off for RSVPing if you decide to show late so please don't let that hold you back...  I'd love for you to all RSVP, but it's definitely not a requirement (the only requirement is to come and have fun!)

Which Panera?... How to find us?...
FAQ - Location, Location, Location... (or at least Panera Bread's Location ;-)


• http://www.meetup.com/Fun-And-Games-Meetup-Tenafly-Northern-New-Jersey-NJ/messages/boards/thread/48006932

Please help us grow!...  please share our group on Google+ & Facebook!

There are "high-res" photos available if you want to print a flyer for work and/or school!

Thanks,

George

a.k.a. Jorge Loco

PS RSVP isn't required, but it'll definitely help me out!

PPS Shall we play a game?

http://www.meetup.com/Fun-And-Games-Meetup-Tenafly-Northern-New-Jersey-NJ/messages/boards/thread/48695815/

results.description:
Great news! PermaBash is Beyond Organic Design's party to celebrate our 3rd Anniversary and the realization of a long-held dream! BOD is partnering with Renaissance Charter School in Queens for the Urban Design & Sustainability Program, the first children's permaculture educational program in a NYC public school! Together, this summer, we'll connect the dots between design, agriculture and sustainability. Italo's BK is providing great food and drink, plus there's live music courtesy of Permajam (www.PermaJam.com) and special guest Kelly Fragale (www.KellyFragle.net). The UDSP is a hands-on, experiential, service-learning program where students will apply permaculture design on a rooftop garden, classroom, and their community as a springboard towards simple but powerful global solutions. The UDSP will offer students a powerful lens to see the world’s interconnectivity and become eco-citizens. They’ll learn how they CAN solve today’s seemingly insurmountable environmental and food challenges. All donations are tax-deductible and pay for much-needed supplies for the UDSP. BOD Founder Monica Ibacache leads a brief presentation about the UDSP before music starts at 5 pm. To learn more about the UDSP, please visit http://bit.ly/23saMyF. Space is limited for the PermaBash, so get your tickets now at www.BeyondOrganicDesign.com! Your $20 donation comes with two beverage tickets. Or you can order tickets in advance for only $15 at www.BeyondOrganicDesign.com.

When: Sunday, April 24, 2016
Time: 4:30 to 10 pm
Where: Italo’s BK, 895 Broadway, Brooklyn (Bushwick), NY
1 minute to JMZ stop at Myrtle / Broadway
results.name: BOD's 3rd Anniversary! Let's Party for a Great Cause!

The UDSP is a hands-on, experiential, service-learning program where students will apply permaculture design on a rooftop garden, classroom, and their community as a springboard towards simple but powerful global solutions. 

The UDSP will offer students a powerful lens to see the world’s interconnectivity and become eco-citizens. They’ll learn how they CAN solve the seemingly insurmountable environmental and food challenges we face today. All donations are tax-deductible and pay for much-needed supplies for the UDSP. BOD Founder Monica Ibacache will lead a brief presentation about the UDSP before music starts at 5 pm. To learn more about the UDSP, please visit http://bit.ly/23saMyF. 

Space is limited for the PermaBash, so get your tickets now at <a>www.BeyondOrganicDesign.com!</a> Your $20 donation comes with two beverage tickets. Or you can order tickets in advance for only $15 at <a>www.BeyondOrganicDesign.com.</a>

Time: 4:30 to 10 pm
Where: Italo’s BK, 895 Broadway, Brooklyn (Bushwick), NY

results.description:
Knit+Wine Night is purely a social gathering of knitters and crocheters who each bring their own projects to work on, enjoy one another's company -- and drink wine! We are a diverse group and welcome all who want to join us. We help each another when necessary, but there is no formal instruction. 

Each month's MeetUp is capped at 20 attendees, as that is the absolute most the restaurant can accommodate. 

Advance RSVP *for each attendee* is required in order to attend. Please note: The MeetUp system will not allow you to RSVP unless you have paid the $2 fee via Paypal.
results.name: April Knit+Wine Night

results.description:
It's been awhile since our last get-together, so let's go to an uptown institution, the United Palace, for a free film outing! This Sunday, please join us to see "Singin' in the Rain". We'll meet in the lobby between 4:30 - 4:45pm. We'll comment on the event page where the group ends up sitting and if we end up getting drinks or dinner afterwards (if so, probably around 7:30pm).

Doors open at 4:30, Pre-movie entertainment starts at 5pm, and the movie starts at 5:30pm.

Please bring $2 in cash to keep the Meet Up going. Hope to see you there!

Anna


From the event website:

The pre-show entertainment will include singin', dancin', and a vintage clothin' fashin' show by The New York Vintage Enthusiasts. They focus on celebrating the fashion, dance, and culture of bygone eras, especially the 1920's-1950's.  They will present a variety of looks inspired by the film, which was made in the 1950's but set in the Roaring Twenties. The Bathtub Ginnys will also perform a song and dance number from Singin' In the Rain. They are a ladies' dance trio presenting chorus girl entertainment with a musical theater flair.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll meet in the lobby between 4:30 - 4:45pm
results.name: "Singing in the Rain" at United Palace

results.description:
Welcome to the City of Grimm, the perfect place to hire a thief or cutthroat, the only place where the shadows outnumber the people.

You've been offered a position in the longstanding Guild of Thieves and Assassins, otherwise known as "The Rookery". You will be meeting the other prospects at midnight, at the back table of the Hanged Mann Inn. There, you will be given a test. Pass the test and gain membership. Fail, and you won't see morning. Good luck.

"Parliament of Rooks" is a new adventure by DM Lewis Mancine. It will be 8 sessions long, using the Pathfinder game system. Characters start at 3rd level and there is a max of 6 players.
results.name: Pathfinder: "Parliament of Rooks" by Lewis Mancine PC Building Session

results.description:
5:00-5:15: Requisite fifteen minute schmoozing.
5:15-6:15: We write for an hour, a la the "Shut Up & Write" meetups.
6:15-6:25: Replenish mind and body after intense and gratifying writing session via the ordering of food and drink.
6:25-8:00: We critique, in a a supportive way, two pieces from group members. The two pieces will have been designated the previous week. These files are available through the "Files" section on this site.
8:00: Sad farewells, until next week.

We look forward to seeing you at the Sunday AWG Meetup. Any questions, please feel free to contact us through this site.

PLEASE NOTE: You must attend at least one meetup before submitting a piece for review.

PLEASE NOTE AGAIN: It's probably a good idea to bring headphones and a music player, as it's unpredictable what sort of background noise is going to be going on during the writing session.

All files to be critiqued on Sunday are available from the "Files" section, which is under the "More" Menu at the top of the page. The direct link to the "Files" page is:

http://www.meetup.com/astoriawritersgroup/files/

Meet at the wooden gazebo located at the 48th St. side of the park at the lower level by the water. It's located not too far from the bathrooms near the street ramp. You can also click the location link near the meetup date & time for a Google Earth GPS view of the meetup location.

The walk will take approximately 45-60 minutes depending on how much we walk. We can walk more if the group decides to. I'll wait around 5 minutes before walking. If you're running late, post a notification and we'll wait.

Join the Uptown Gamers every other Sunday for tabletop games at the Whole Foods dining area on the Upper West Side (Located on the corner of 97th st. and Columbus Ave.). results.description:
"The Art of Thinking" is about taking personal responsibility for our own thoughts.

The Author BK Jayanti is a spiritual teacher and leader , a gifted meditator and an emissary for peace and a much sought-after speaker around the world.

She currently serves as the European Director of the Brahma Kumaris World Spiritual University and assists in co-coordinating the university's activites in more than 100 countries and is also its main representative to the United Nations.

In this short but powerful booklet of 50 pages Bk Jayanti explains how to separate our inner life from our outer life and how to train the mind to create & sustain positive thoughts.Through the study and practice of this art, she shows how even our feelings and our relationships can be transformed.

Come join us for a book reading and casual conversation on the Book 'THE ART OF THINKING"  on Sunday April 24th at 6pm athe Global Harmony House meditation and learning center , 46 south middle neck rd, Great Neck , Ny, 11021,[masked] 0971.

If you wish to buy the book  for $3 go to amazon.com or feel free to buy it at theGlobal Harmony House the day of the event.

Even if you choose not to purchase a copy we will provide you with printed handouts for selected sections we will covering.

To see course offerings which all are offered free as a community service in any of our locations in  either great neck, queens , manhattan or upstate new york  (Peace Village retreat center) , go to www.brahmakumaris.org/us/newyork
results.how_to_find_us: train- from penn station take LIRR,Port washington Line to Great neck , 5 minute walk to Harmony House, By Car exit 33 (lakeville road)on the LIE(495) travel north lakeville rd , pass northern blvd , 2 traffic lights after northern blvd , left side
results.name: "THE ART OF THINKING" Book Club meeting & Casual Conversation , April 24th

results.description:
This month we'll be going to Meske, a fine Ethiopian restaurant in west Midtown.  A menu is here.  Ethiopian food is served on a 1/4" thick layer of soft bread.  You tear off little pieces of bread and use it to pick up your food -- it's a lot of fun!  The food is a little bit like Indian food, but not (quite) as spicy.

A $5 *DEPOSIT* is required to RSVP, which will be *REFUNDED* *IN* *CASH* 10 minutes after the event starts.  No-shows and latecomers forfeit their deposit.  You will receive an electronic refund if you change your RSVP to "no" more than 24 hours before the event.


---------------------------------------------------------------

You wouldn't know it from watching the evening news, but it is well documented that, over the centuries and millenia, humans have been becoming increasingly non-violent.  And, looking back, we observe that values have been becoming increasingly like our own.  Some extrapolate this trend to conclude that it means that the future will bring more of what we like, even labeling anyone who disagrees with us as "on the wrong side of history".  But if we look at the present through the eyes of the past and extrapolate from that, we are led to the conclusion that the future will be profoundly unacceptable to us.


---------------------------------------------------------------

President Woodrow Wilson, prior to being president of the United States, was president of Princeton University, and, as a result, has his name on many of the school's institutions and buildings.

He was also frankly very racist, by modern standards.  He was strongly pro-segregation, and a fan of the KKK.

As a result, students are protesting and demanding that his name be removed from every institution and building on the campus.

A similar movement is afoot to purge Harvard University of the names of dead people whose beliefs and actions fail to pass muster by contemporary standards.

Basically what's happened is that universities are running out of live bigots to purge, so they're moving on to the dead ones.  The McCarthy Era only lasted a few years, and ran its course before they exhausted their supply of live leftists to torment, but had it drawn on for a few decades, they probably would have eventually started purging dead ones, too.


As tonight's first topic illustrates, we have no idea what the values of people in the future will be, hence even less idea of how we will look in their eyes.

But I will make a prediction: the present diet of most Americans will be thoroughly morally unacceptable to people 100 years from now.  Raising beef for food requires huge amounts of land and resources, and will be unsustainable as the population grows.  What's more, we will develop ways to grow meat substitutes in vats, which will be cheaper, tastier, more nutritious, and safer in terms of pathogens than eating real meat is now.  No one will eat meat.  And how will these people view us?  To them, the moral compromises necessary to kill animals for our food, especially when we know full well that we could survive, cheaply and in good health, as vegetarians, will seem depraved and repugnant to them.  Will they purge our names from public records as a shameful memory?

While Europe was in the dark ages, the knowledge of the ancient Greeks was preserved in libraries in the Middle East.  Where would we be now if the prophet Mohammed had decreed that the ancient Greeks, being polytheists (he couldn't stand polytheists), and being tolerant of gays, were a "debased" influence, and ordered all memory of them purged from Islamic libraries?


---------------------------------------------------------------

With the implosion of the Warsaw Pact, we in the West have developed a conceit that all other societies are on a trajectory that will lead to institutions and values like our own, and that all that other countries want is to integrate peacefully into the world order the US has laid down.  This piece suggests that China is on a much more sinister path.
results.how_to_find_us: Just East of the Corner of 10th Ave.  I'll have a sign on the table, and I look like my picture, plus a mustache.
results.name: Ethiopian Food, The Unacceptable Future, Banning Dead Bigots, China's Game Plan

results.description:
Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

Meet other members for a brief happy hour mingle while guests arrive.  Once everyone has checked-in you'll be seated for your series of four minute "mini-dates." On your dating card that you receive at check-in, you'll select who you wish to see again. You can choose Dating or Friendship as your preferred connection.

We will collect everyone's dating cards at the end of the event and email you your mutual matches within 48 hours.

While this event is geared towards helping people meet potential romantic matches, you can also mingle with all the guests and find new friends as well.

On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24  - PAY IN ADVANCE ONLY - WE DO NOT ACCEPT PAYMENT AT DOOR

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: https://2016atwysnycspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.


OUR METHOD:

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's  more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. 

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.
results.name: SpeedMeeting - Singles Ages 32-44 1F/3M spots left

group.name: Advanced Degree Singles in NYC - Ages 21-55

results.description:
TNYA Water Polo is an LGBTQ friendly team with practices at John Jay Sunday from 6:00 – 7:30 pm, and Tuesday 8:00 or 9:00 - 10:00 pm at the Chelsea Rec Center (for Rec Center  members only). For full information on the team, please go to 

www.tnya.org

The first practice is free and we love getting new players! Please let the coach on deck know if it's your first time with us and feel free to message Alex Barclay ahead of time if you have any questions. You will need to bring a swim suit appropriate for water polo, a towel, goggles and a lock. If you would like to practice with us regularly, you must become registered with US Water Polo at the silver level and pay our annual membership dues. 

We ask that any practice participants have some prior experience playing water polo and be able to swim a hundred yards in a row in less than two minutes. If you have a swimming background and are interested in learning water polo, please read the pdf below thoroughly and contact Alex Barclay. The coaching is typically geared to an intermediate level of play and we do work on basic skills at every practice. Everyone should be familiar with the basic rules and concepts of the game, as outlined in this pdf: 

http://www.tnya.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/Polo_Beginners.pdf

Practices typically include a swim set and some conditioning at the beginning, drills, and scrimmaging for the last 30-45 minutes (it's also ok to sit out and watch for the scrimmaging portion if it's your first practice). The first and third Sundays are geared towards scrimmaging and the second and fourth are more focused on skills and/or conditioning. Bob or Jeff are the typical coaches. We strive to create a positive and welcoming environment and do not tolerate any unsportsmanlike conduct. There are at least four tournaments we compete in each year and practices will adjust in the weeks before the tournaments to prepare participating players.

Hosted by Team New York Aquatics. Coached by Bob.

Welcomes all levels including beginners.

Free for first timers. Bring goggles, swimsuit, towel, and lock for gym locker.
results.name: TNYA hosts All Level Water Polo

results.description:
Dear Yogis & Yoginis:


Greetings! ^_^

Welcome to my FREE beginner yoga class coming up this Sunday! 

Last Sunday we had a well-rounded beginner class where we had a wonderful time together, generating heat & positive energy, as well as gaining the stillness of mind and inner peace within during and after our practice. This week, I'd like to invite you all to come to a world of a pain-free neck and flexible shoulders.

You probably look like this:

or this

BEFORE my class. But you'll look and feel more like this:

or this:


or this:

*AFTER my class*! 

In this modern time, as we spend hours and hours sitting in front of our computers and hunching over our smartphones and tablets, this class is a much needed one that benefits almost all of us who live in a digital society.

As usual, the class this week is open to yoga lovers, in particular, beginners. It emphasizes the fundamentals of yoga through informative instructions. As intermediate to advanced yogis may find it too simple, it is always good to go back to the basics to refine our alignments of asanas (steady and easeful yoga postures). Actually, advanced yogis and athletes would especially benefit from the deep relaxation and freeing of tensions held in their muscles that this gentle yoga class offers. With that being said, you are all warmly welcomed! :)

The studio is located on the 9th Avenue and in between W 50th Street & W 51st Street in NYC. Please press the button "Sonic Yoga" and the secretary will buzz you in. After you enter the building, head directly to the 3rd Floor, where the studio is located.

Please kindly bring a yoga mat with you. If you do not have one, you can rent it for $2 at the studio. Props are free of charge. Restrooms and shower rooms are available for use. No lockers so feel free to bring your valuable items with you into the studio room.



Important Notes: 


1) The class will start at 6:15 SHARP so please arrive at least 5 minutes earlier for sign-in and the setting up of your mats and props. Warming up is essential in avoiding injuries in doing yoga so you don't want to miss that. ;)

2) Please take off your shoes before you enter the room on the 3rd floor.

2) Please put your phone in silent or airplane mode if you decide to take it with you into the studio.

3) Please return all the props and mats properly to the conditions they were in upon leaving. Your cooperation is much appreciated!

Caution: Your neck and shoulders will fall in love with me lol... 

Love and light.

Namaste, 

Shuai
results.how_to_find_us: It is located on the 9th Avenue and in between W 50th Street & W 51st Street in NYC. Please press the button "Sonic Yoga" and the secretary will buzz you in. After you enter the building, head directly to the 3rd Floor, where the studio is located.
results.name: FREE Beginner Yoga Class for Stiff Neck and Tight Shoulders

Each week dozens of CRC members and friends gather following the 5:30 mass at Holy Trinity to socialize, network and connect.  It is a great way to meet others in the group in a fun and casual way.

This week we will be going to Firehouse Tavern who has donated to our charity events in the past.  Hang out at the bar and socialize or sit and have a bite to eat with the group, separate checks are no problem. 

Can I come alone?  Yes, Sunday is the best time to come on your own as almost everyone comes on their own.  Dave will be on hand to welcome everyone old and new.

Do I need to be a member of Holy Trinity Parish? No many of our members belong to other parishes.

What if I went to the earlier mass?  Not a problem, come for the gathering and enjoy food and drink

The group will meet on the sidewalk after mass (approx 6:30pm) then walk over together or you can meet us at the restaurant.
results.name: After Mass Gathering at Firehouse Tavern
